characters: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
SHOT OF NEATLY GROOMED FRONT YARD
SHOT OF NEATLY GROOMED BACKYARD WITH NEW SWING SET
FAMILY PHOTO OF ARCTOR, HIS WIFE, AND TWO
SHOT OF NOTEBOOK PAGE DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
SHOT OF DONNA HAWTHORNE TOUCHING ARCTOR'S HAND

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: A massive, unlit Coca-Cola sign is eerily silhouetted against the early morning sky. Antiquated delivery trucks set out from loading docks, as red futuristic cargo plane emblazoned with the Coca-Cola logo, take off from the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds-eye view of Coca-Cola trucks spreading out through city. Coke planes shoot by close to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 7-11
dialogues.text: A Coke truck pulls into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Coke plane lands gracefully on the roof of the supermar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uniformed delivery men enter, hauling cases of Coke syrup

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Coca-Cola truck rumbles slowly past a row of low-income plastic pre-fab houses. We hold on one house whose front lawn is strewn with furniture and cleaning products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows are spray-painted over with silver paint. A single pole lamp with bare, harsh spot-lights illuminates the room, which is emptied of furniture, covered in a sic green shag carpet, and littered with fast-food wrappers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: the center of the room stands Jerry Fabin, thirty, with w eyes and a long, tangled mass of hair. He is naked, drape over a metal garbage can, and vigorously scratching his head. This process continues for an uncomfortably long time. A Golden Retriever sleeps in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Fabin stands under a hot shower. Steam fills the stall. He scrubs his hair violently with tensed fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the shower. Steam pours out the open bathroom doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is high; the day is bright and hazy.   A few hipp stroll by or sit on front steps, discreetly smoking joint We hear the distant sound of Jerry's shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is still in the shower, scrubbing away. He finally turns it off and steps out, a drowned rat. He dries himself, wipes the mirror and squints nervously at his reflection. Tiny bugs hop around on his head. He screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry lies on the cruddy shag carpet, open volumes of the Encyclopedia Brittanica spread around him. He scratches himself as he studies one of the volumes. Insects hop up down all over his body, and on the rug. When he exhales, cloud of bugs pours from his mouth; he shoos them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry heads up the walkway carrying a shopping bag. Sever cans of Raid and other bug sprays poke out of the bag. Bu hop around on Jerry. He puts the bag down on the stoop to scratch himself. He notices tiny bugs chewing the shrubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry consults with a man behind the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating the bushes?   Could be aphids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aphids! Of course. Y'know, I started with "A" in my cyclopedia, yet somehow I must've skipped right over aphids. It does start with "A", right? Aphids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Yes, it does, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, those fuckers can really bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aphids don't bite people. Fabin just stares at the clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrawled charts depicting the aphid life-cycle now adorn walls. As Jerry sprays a can of "Aphid-Off" around the room, he notices his sleeping dog is covered with the bug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stands in the shower with his dog. Jerry is lathere head-to-toe and in the process of lathering the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry and the long-suffering dog are still in the shower. Charles Freck, early thirties and stoned, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jerry, I was in the neighborhood looking to score, and I thought -- What the fuck are you doing in the shower with the goddamn dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get the aphids. Jerry turns off the shower, steps out with the dog, and begins drying him. Freck watches silently, transfixed, as Jerry proceeds to rub oil, then talc into the dog's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see any aphids. What's an aphid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy) It eventually kills you.       That's what an aphid is. Freck nods sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in my hair and my skin and my lungs. The goddamn pain is unbearable. I'm gonna have to go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, squints) How come I can't see them though? Jerry stops talcing the dog, looks up at Freck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry and Freck are on all fours on the carpet. Bugs hop all around. The powdered-white dog sleeps in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find an especially big one, cause they're hard for many people to see. Jerry grabs a bug from the carpet, throws it in a jar, an clamps the lid down fast. He shows it triumphantly to Fre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!    That is a big one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me find more for the doctor to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are still on their hands and knees collecting bugs. Three jars are already full of hopping insects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we get for these? I mean, does the doctor pay a bounty or something? A prize? Any bread?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get to help perfect a cure for them. They continue to collect bugs in silence. Jerry starts scratching himself again, trying not to be too obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you continue while I take a leak and like that. Jerry heads to the bathroom. The dog, who has been sleepi near the bathroom door, skulks to the other side of the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, these bugs sort of scare me.    I don't like it here by myself. Jerry stops, holds the door jam for support.    He is in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a chickenshit bastard, Freck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to take a leak and like that! Jerry enters the bathroom, slams the door shut, and locks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry turns on the shower, climbs in and begins to soap himself vigorously. Freck is barely audible throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid out here, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go fuck yourself, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do these fuckers bite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah they bite! They're aphids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I wash them off and wait for you? Jerry ignores Freck. He scrubs himself intently, ritualistically, totally absorbed in his task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear pronounced, rhythmic breathing, as we scan the ha which is filled with middle-aged businessmen wearing an array of brightly colored suits. They are well-fed and du looking. At the podium is another bussinessman, this one in a pink suit and yellow tie. He addresses the assemblag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, we have a wonderful opportunity this afternoon. The county of Orange has provided us with the chance to hear from -- and put questions to -- an undercover narcotics agent from the Sheriff's Office. The fat businessman gestures with a sweep of his arm towa the camera. The heavy breathing stops as we angle on what the fat businessman is gesturing toward: a generic blur of a huma being sitting on stage. The blur is clearly human, but it impossible to settle on its facial features. It's as if t features keep changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you will notice that you can barely see this individual becuase he is wearing what is called a "scramble suit", which he wears during most of his daily activities of law enforcement. Due to potential corruption within the Sheriff's Department, even this gallant officer's co-workers and superiors must not know his "street" identity. Heavy breathing. Again we're inside the suit. Now we see, in shadowy profile, the face of the man in the suit. This Bob Arctor, early thirties, homely, and looking like a druggie. He scans the audience disdainfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under breath) Nitwits. Pathetic, soulless morons. We cut to the outside of the suit -- still expressionless

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man -- whom we will call Fred, because that is the code name under which he reports the information he

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FAT BUSINESSMAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gathers -- cannot be identified by voice or by appearance. He looks, does he not, like a vague blur. This is because his scramble suit projects thousands of different human faces onto your retinas, thus turning Fred into a veritable Everyman. All things to all people translates into nothing to anyone, does it not? The fat businessman smiles a big, toothy smile.   The aud of straights smiles back, almost in unison. FAT BUSINESSMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's hear it for our vague blur! The audience erupts into enthusiastic applause. Fred rise and replaces the fat businessman behind the podium. When speaks it is an emotionless computer voice. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you saw me on the street, you'd say, "There goes a weirdo freak doper." And you'd feel aversion and walk away. The audience is silent, blank, their blankness a reflecti of the blankness of Fred's scramble suit. FRED (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't look like you. I can't afford to. My life depends on it. Dramatic pause. FRED (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not going to tell you first what I'm attempting to do as an undercover officer. I'm going to tell you... (beat) ... what I am afraid of. Now the audience is hooked, their eyes wide. We move inside the suit and watch Bob Arctor watching the audience, timing the pause for best effect. We hear the breathing again, and when Arctor speaks, it is in his nor voice, bored, delivering a memorized speech. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I fear, is that our children, your children and my children... (pause) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I have two. Little ones.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRLS
dialogues.text: The Arctor in the photo is different, conservative, in a colorful suit like the audience members. His wife and kid are smiling and suburban-looking. Their features indistin generic, impossible to recall. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not too little to be addicted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is speaking from inside the suit. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... calculatedly addicted, for profit, by those who would destroy this society. We do not yet know who these animals are who pray on our young, but one day we will. VOICE FROM CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sock it to 'em! The audience concurs.   Bob Arctor sighs disdainfully. Outside the suit, the sigh is heard as a computer-like exhalation, uninterpretable, lost on the audience. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe there is one source for Substance D and a diversified distribution system making it accessible in all major drug using areas. It my job as an undercover officer to attain the confidence of low level dealers and work my way up through the network to arrive at the drug's source. Now, the profits for... Fred becomes silent, stands there.   The audience waits. Inside the suit, Arctor sweats, can't remember his line. looks, panicked, out at the sea of eyes and finally wings BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it isn't the profits anyhow. It's something else... what you see ...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arctor scans the hard audience. He tries a new tack. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were a diabetic, and you didn't have the money for insulin, would you steal to get the money? Or just die? A tinny voice speaks to Arctor through his headphone. HEADPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better go back to the prepared text, Fred. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly into throat mike) I forgot it. HEADPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riiight. I'll read it to you. Repeat it after me, but try to make it sound casual. "Each day the profits flow. Where they go we will soon determine." BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I got a block against this stuff. HEADPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Then retribution will swiftly follow. And at that moment, for the life of me, I would not be in their shoes." BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You know why I've got a block against this stuff? Because this bullshit is what gets people on dope. The audience watches the vague blur mumbling in a compute voice. They look uneasy. Fred is silent for a moment, the starts to talk again in his drone. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "D" is for Substance D. Which is for Dumbness, Despair, and Desertion, the desertion of your friends from you, you from them, everyone from everyone, isolation and loneliness and hating and suspecting each other. D is finally death. Slow Death, we... (beat) ... we the dopers call it...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Inside the suit, Bob Arctor talks. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raspy, sad) ... Slow Death. From the head on down. (beat) Well, that's it. Arctor goes back to his seat.   The audience is angry. HEADPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See me in my office when you get back. The fat businessman is at the podium diffusing the situat FAT BUSINESSMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to tell you that Fred asked me in advance to make this lecture primarily a Q and A forum with only a short introductory statement. So any questions? Arctor stands. FAT BUSINESSMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait, it appears Fred has something else to say. Good, then. (to Arctor) Please. Arctor approaches the podium, upset. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just this. Don't kick their asses after they're on it. Half of them, especially the girls, didn't know they were getting on anything at all. See, the pushers dissolve some reds in a glass of wine, they give the booze to an underage little chick, she passes out, then they inject her with a mex hit -- half heroin, half Substance D. (beat) Thank you. SECOND VOICE FROM CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we stop them, sir? We're outside the suit now, looking at Fred the vague blu behind the podium. He talks in a neutral computer voice.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill the pushers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Freck is on the phone, speaking in hushed tones. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you lay about ten Deaths on me? TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I'm looking to score myself. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. (beat) Christ. Christ Christ Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck drives slowly along a strip-malled Anaheim street. passes a Thrifty pharmacy and notices the window display: bottles of slow death, slow death mixed with speed and ju and psychedelics. Dayglow signs in the window: "Your Credit is Good Here" and "Death to the Masses" He looks again. The window displays combs and shampoo. Freck check his rearview mirror, sees a police car following him. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking goddamn fuzzmobile. What was I doing? Was I weaving? I don't even know. Freck drives very deliberately, his hands gripped, white- knuckled, on the steering wheel in an attempt to keep the completely straight. He tries his best to plaster a non- stoned, regular guy look on his face. But he's sweating. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'll do is pull over when I see a parking space. That's it: pull over like I was gonna pull over anyway. Like it's totally normal to pull over. Like I'm going to a store. That's perfect. Real people do that all the time. Freck sees an angle space, pulls over suddenly. The cop c glides past, apparently having had no interest in Freck.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fucking fuzz. Now I'll never be able to pull back into traffic. Freck sighs, resigns himself to waiting in his parking sp and checking out the young, mini-skirted women walking by CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping score) Fox... fox... not a fox... fo...hey, I know that fox! Freck opens his car door and jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck hurries after a pretty young woman, nineteen, with black hair. This is Donna Hawthorne. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Donna realizes that Freck is following her and picks up h pace. The sidewalk is crowded with people. Donna weaves through, graceful and fast. Freck struggles to catch up. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! The light is against her at the corner and while the othe pedestrians wait for the WALK sign, Donna juts out into traffic, causing a Coke truck to swerve and honk. She giv it the finger. Freck waits with the others till the light changes. Then he runs, catches up with Donna, and walks backwards ahead of her, sweating and panting. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna! She ignores him, keeps walking. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you Bob Arctor's old lady? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (pulls out a little pocket knife, points it at Freck) Get lost. He widens the distance between them to avoid getting stuc

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you are. I met you at his place. Donna turns and walks directly toward Freck, her little k pointing at his stomach. He jumps out of the way. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez.   I just... Donna keeps walking. Freck shrugs and slouches dejectedly away. He turns and gives one last glance over his shoulde Donna has stopped amid the bustling foot traffic. She is squinting at him. Freck cautiously approaches her. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One night me and Bob and another chick had some old Simon and Garfunkel tapes. You were filling caps with high-grade Death, then you laid one on each of us. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to knock me down and bang me. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just wondered if you, like, wanted a ride or... Bang you on the sidewalk? In broad daylight? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might pull me into a doorway or something. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. Besides Arctor would snuff me if I did that. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't recognize you.    I'm sort of nearsighted. Donna moves a few steps closer to Freck and squints at hi CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride where you're going? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll bang me in the car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. Besides I can't get it up these days. Must be something they're adulterating all the stuff with. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a neat-o line, but I've heard it before. Everybody bangs me. At least they try to. That's what it's like to be a chick. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really sucks. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm suing one guy right now for molestation and assault. We're asking punitive damages in excess of forty thousand. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far he get? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand around my boob. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not worth forty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck drives Donna home. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you got anything to sell?    I'm really hurting. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get it. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tabs, though. I don't shoot up. Needles are a bummer to me. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty dollars a hundred. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, man, that's a burn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're super good. Take my word. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.     A hundred, then. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.     How do I get in touch? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles B. Freck -- Donna pulls a little pad and a pencil from her purse and writes down Freck's name. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V. Freck? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Freck. She corrects the name. Freck notices that her writing is slow and childish scrawl. It makes him sad. Then he steal a glance at her breasts as she writes. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)
She writes down the phone number. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I remember you now. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you want to go with me to see Jerry Fabin? I'm hauling some of his stuff over to the Number Three Federal Clinic where they took him last night. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better not. Jerry thinks I contaminated him originally with those bugs. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're aphids. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, then he didn't know what they were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Arctor, now out of his scramble suit and looking like druggie, wanders depressed and aimless along a crowded street. He passes a McDonald's, a 7-11, a mirrored office building, pulls a pill box from his pocket, and surreptitiously swallows two capsules. He studies his reflection in the office building. Behind him on the stre are the disapproving reflections of passing straights. He blends back into the flow of foot traffic. A grungy hippy smiles at him. Arctor nods, passes another McDonald's. He passes a third McDonald's almost immediately. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking McDonaldburger's is taking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor dials the phone and takes a bite from a partially unwrapped McDonald's hamburger. He chews as the phone rin DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna.   How you doin'? It's Bob. DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Oh.    Hi. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your head today, man? DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh. I was bumtripped this a.m. by my boss. This gray hair bilked us out of ten bucks. So my boss says it's coming out of my paycheck! BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can I get anything from you? DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resistant) I don't know. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten.   Just ten.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. I'll come over tonight. Hey, I have this book I want to show you. About wolves. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what the male wolf does when he defeats a foe? He doesn't snuff him. He pees on him! Then he splits. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I peed on some people today. DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?    How come? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metaphorically peed, I mean. DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the usual way? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is, I told this group of... Arctor realizes he's saying too much. He tries to cover. He glances at a Foster's Freeze across the street with so Hell's Angels in the parking lot. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... biker-types, at the Foster's Freeze. I was cruising around and they said something raunchy, so I turned and said something like -- Arctor has no idea what to say.    Suddenly he's exhauste DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell me, even if it's super gross. You have to be super gross with biker-types. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told 'em I'd rather ride a pig than a hog. DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.) (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a pig is a chick that -- DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, well I get it. Barf. Oh, I forgot to tell you, your roommates, Ernie What's-His-Name and Barris, came into the shop today looking for you. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't try me at my job, did they? DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. They said they wanted to use your cephalochromoscope and it didn't work. So Barris took it apart -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you say -- DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And apparently it's been sabotaged. The wires cut, and sort of weird stuff like that. Barris said he'd -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Barris! That cephscope cost me nine hundred dollars. I need to get home right now. But I gotta... Oh, fuck, man. Fuck fuck fuck Barris! DONNA HAWTHORNE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta what? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta run an errand and like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor parks across from the New-Path Drug Rehab Facility converted wood frame house. He checks the police photo of Erroll Weeks, a.k.a Spade Weeks, shoves it into his glove compartment, and heads, business-like, toward the buildin

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK PAGE DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Children play in the background. Someone skims the entry, the offhand voice-over reads along. BOB ARCTOR   (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The S.O. believes Spade   Weeks has lost himself inside New-Path   by posing as a junky. New-Path strips    junkies of all (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i.d. and gives them new names as part of personality rebuilding process. It's a perfect hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gloomy. There's a lounge area with a couple of guys reading. An unused ping-pong table. Posters on the wall such as THE ONLY REAL FAILURE IS TO FAIL OTHERS. Arctor enters, now playing the junky: strung-out, disoriented. A pretty girl in a New-Path tee-shirt appears. NEW-PATH GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a bad place. I wanna turn myself in for treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Freck and Jim Barris sit in a booth. Freck plays distractedly with his glazed doughnut. Barris, in shades, pulls apart his patty melt, inspecting each ingredient. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Barris, I'm thinking of turning myself in to New-Path. Barris doesn't seem at all interested. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's tough, that cold turkey thing they do. They watch you night and day so you don't snuff. But they never give you anything, like a doctor will, like Valium or like that. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what kind of bread is this on the patty melt, anyway? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look on the menu. It explains everything. Barris picks up a menu, studies it as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you go into New-Path, you'll experience symptoms that emanate up from the basic fluids of the body, specifically those located in the brain. By that I refer to the catecholamines, such as noradrenaline and serotonin. You see, Substance D functions this way: it interacts with the catecholamines in such a fashion that involement is locked in at a subcellular level. Biological counteradaptation has occurred. (looks up) Nine-grain wheat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits in a small room painted institutional green. holds a styrofoam cup of coffee in his theatrically shaki hands. The New-Path girl stares at him, arms akimbo. Two large impassive guys stand near the door. NEW-PATH GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like hell, mister. NEW-PATH GUY #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like real shit. What you been doing, lying in your own crap? NEW-PATH GUY #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap lying in crap. How appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cute waitress comes up to Barris and Freck's table. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is everything good, fellas? Freck becomes panicked, paranoid. He frantically chews so doughnut, tries to appear straight. Barris, in control, signals to Freck that everything is copacetic. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, is your name Patty? WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (indicates name tag over right breast) It's Beth.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under breath, snickering) I wonder what the left one's called. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, hon? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Nothing. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress we had last time was named Patty. Same as the sandwich. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been a different Patty from the sandwich. I think she spells it with an i. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is super good. Freck looks over leering Barris's head and sees a thought balloon in which the waitress is stripping off her clothe WAITRESS (IN THOUGHT BALLOON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moaning) Oh, oh, fuck me, Barris. Fuck me... Freck, nervous the waitress will see the balloon, tries t get her attention on him. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is not good with me. I got a lot of problems nobody else has. The waitress looks down sympathetically at Freck. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.   That's too bad. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people than you think have such problems. This is a world of illness, and getting progressively worse. The waitress now looks with some confusion at Barris.   F glances nervously at the balloon above Barris's head.   I the waitress is being fucked from behind by Barris.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WAITRESS (IN THOUGHT BALLOON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, oooh oh, Barris... WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) So would you guys like to order dessert? We have fresh peach pie. Freck can't take his eyes from the thought balloon. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!   No, we don't want any dessert! The waitress smiles, nods, and leaves the table.   The th balloon dissipates. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fruit pies are for old ladies anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits surrounded by the three standing New-Path peo BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is the only hope I could think of. I had a friend come in here. A black dude, in his thirties -- NEW-PATH GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll meet the family later. If you qualify. You have to be bad off to be let in here, mister. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am bad off. NEW-PATH GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be super rough. You'll gnaw your pillow. You'll foam at the mouth. You'll dirty yourself the way sick animals do. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but listen, this black guy, my buddy, goes by the name of Spade, did he make it here? I sure hope he didn't get picked up by the pigs on the way over. NEW-PATH GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no one-to-one relationships at New-Path. You'll learn that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, why the debate regarding turning yourself in for residence therapy at a drug rehab facility? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Jerry Fabin and his aphids. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive wave) Fabin was a special case. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another reason. I'm running low again, and I can't stand this always running low and not knowing if I'm ever going to score again. Actually, though, I may have a new source. That Donna chick. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bob's girl. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His old lady. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   He never got into her pants. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   Can't Bob get it on? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It's possible Donna's on junk. Her aversion to bodily contact -- junkies lose interest in sex, you see, due to their organs swelling up from vasoconstriction. And Donna shows inordinate failure of sexual arousal, not just to Bob, but to... other males as well. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never shot smack. Needles are a bummer to me. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially) But... I can show you how to lay Donna for ninety-eight cents.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to lay her. I just want to buy from her. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna does coke. Anybody who would give her a gram of coke she would undoubtedly spread her legs for. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't talk that way. Besides who has the money to procure a gram of coke? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, my friend, can derive a gram of coke for a total cost to me of under one dollar. From a product readily available at your neighborhood 7-11. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck and Barris drive along. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which 7-11 store do you prefer to shop at? The one on Lincoln is nice. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fine 7-11. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although what about the one on 8th? They have the wider aisles. A more spacious shopping experience. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not forget the one on Katella with the foxy cashier to hit on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mess. Freck is on the couch smoking a joint. A cat sleeps in his lap. Another cat and a dog lie on either si of him. A disassembled cephscope is on the coffee table, wires exposed. Barris hovers over the dining room table where he has set up a makeshift chemistry lab.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with Bob's cephscope, his prize possession of the entire world? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's been sabotaged by person or persons unknown. Barris holds up an aerosol can of Solarcaine sunburn spra JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold, what they've deliberately done is mix the cocaine with oil so it can't be extracted -- they cleverly call it benzocaine -- but my knowledge of chemistry is such that I know precisely how to separate the two. Barris sprays the entire contents of the can into a baggi CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is super unreal. I'm flipping. Barris shakes salt into the gummy slime in the bag. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'll freeze it, which causes the cocaine crystals to rise to the top because they are lighter than air. Barris pours the slime into a jar. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than oil, I mean. Barris puts the jar in the freezer. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The terminal step I keep to myself, but it involves an intricate methodological process of filtering. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you do get a gram of coke out of thisl, I can't use it to get into Donna's pants. That's like buying her. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give her a gift she gives you one. The most precious gift a woman has.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about Bob Arctor's girl, Barris. He's my friend and the guy you and Luckman live with. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a great deal about Bob Arctor you're not aware of. Your view is simplistic and naive, and you believe about him what he wants you to. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) I do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, in a scramble suit, talks to Hank, also in a scram suit and studying a clipboard. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That covers Barris and Freck. Let's see, I guess we can write Jerry Fabin off. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read his EEG analysis.    Fabin's over. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good riddance. Any luck locating our missing pusher friend Spade Weeks? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New-Path wouldn't tell me shit. They're very protective of their own. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junkies, ex-junkies. It's a club. (flipping through notes) What about Donna Hawthorne? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep pumping her for more and more Death. Pretty soon she'll have to refer me up to her source. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   And what's Arctor up to? We go inside Fred's suit and see the shadowy face of Arct

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Arctor? He's not doing anything much. Working at his nowhere Blue Chip Stamp job, dropping a few tabs of meth cut with Death during the day. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I hear. Arctor studies the vague blankness of Hank. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a tip that Arctor has funds above and beyond what he makes at the stamp redemption center. We move outside the suit and see Fred. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit, Hank. Is that true? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And according to this information, Arctor comes and goes mysteriously. Have you observed any of this? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most likely he's with his chick, Donna. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most likely?    You're supposed to know. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's Donna. He's over there banging her day and night. But I'll let you know. So, who's the informant? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, we don't know. No voice print. He used one of those rinky-dink grids. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, it's that burned-out acid head Barris doing a schizy grudge job on Arctor's head. I wouldn't give him the time of day as an informant.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know it's Barris. Anyway, there may be more to Barris than meets the eye. We're looking into him. Nothing I feel would be of use to you, at least so far. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's one of Arctor's friends. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Undoubtedly a vengeance burn trip. But we need to know why Arctor's making these kind of enemies. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, I don't see this as an avenue of
HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm taking you off Spade and, for the time being, I'm assigning you primarily to observe Bob Arctor. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strangled robot noise) You're assigning me to watch Arctor? We move inside Fred's suit and watch an uncomfortable, sweaty Arctor watching Hank. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Covertly funded, covertly engaged, Fred. It's worth checking into. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. So I assume this means you'll be bugging Arctor's house and car? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the new holographic scanner system. This way you can study Arctor's every move on the tapes, and report back to us in detail. Hank, the vague blur, looks up at Fred.   Fred, the vague blur, returns his look. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good, then.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You'll need to get Arctor and the boys away from the house so we can install the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yard, lit only by moonlight, is overgrown with weeds littered with rubbish. Barris sits on a cracked cement patio fiddling with some sort of foam rubber and aluminum foil tube. Freck looks on anxiously. Ernie Luckman, a big stoner in a football jersey, sits on a decrepit swing set looks up at the moon, and sips a beer. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you need a silencer, anyway, Jim? I mean, they're illegal. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law abidance has always been of the utmost concern to Jim Barris. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this day and age, with the kind of degenerate society we live in and the depravity of the individual, every person of worth needs a gun at all times. To protect himself. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just shut up and fire off the great eleven cent silencer of our times. Barris half shuts his eyes and fires the pistol into the air. It is the loudest report ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor jerks awake and reflexively grabs his gun from und his pillow. Confused, heart pounding, he tries to take in his surroundings. Dogs bark outside.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some silencer, man. JIM BARRIS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it did was augment the sound rather than dampen it. But I almost have it right. I have it in principal, anyhow. Arctor sighs, replaces the gun, and gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor trudges through the pig-sty living room, past the ratty couch, the broken cephscope, the crooked pictures o the wall. He disappears into the kitchen. CHARLES FRECK (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is a gun like that worth? JIM BARRIS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.   Thirty bucks. I'll sell it to you. Arctor reappears, leans against the kitchen door, beer in hand, and looks at the depressing living room. JIM BARRIS (O.S.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really ought to have one to protect yourself, Freck, against those who would harm you. ERNIE LUCKMAN (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of those. I saw in the L.A. Times yesterday, they're giving away a free transistor radio to those who would harm Freck most successfully. Arctor studies the empty couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same room, but different. It's neat. The picture on the wall are straight. A younger, cleaner, straighter Bob Arctor sits on the couch watching tv with his wife an children. Through shadow and obstruction, we never get a clear view of Arctor's family.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TELEVISION JINGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's real, it's Coke, it's really, really real. Really really really... WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popcorn and Cokes, guys? DAUGHTERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yay, Popcorn and Cokes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The catchy, reduntant Coke jingle continues in the background throughout. Bob Arctor squats down and reaches into a floor level cabinet to grab a popcorn popper. When rises, he hits his head hard on a sharp corner. His countenance changes dramatically, violently. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: AH, FUCK
dialogues.text: WIFE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey? Arctor drops to the floor, pressing his hand against his bleeding scalp. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: FUCKING POPCORN POPPER
dialogues.text: Arctor's wife and daughters appear in the doorway.   We s them from behind, looking at Arctor. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Arctor's wife runs to him. His daughters hover in the doorway. Arctor looks up at his wife, at his daughters.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK PAGE DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Kids playing in background.   A dispassionate Arctor read the handwritten entry. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That pain, so unexpected, so undeserved, cleared away the cobwebs in my head. I didn't hate the popcorn popper, I hated my wife and kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor bleeds, his wife hovers, the jingle persists. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NEATLY GROOMED BACKYARD WITH NEW SWING SET
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated my backyard,...

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NEATLY GROOMED FRONT YARD
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my front yard,... Arctor, in shorts, appears pushing a lawnmower. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my power mower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits on the floor bleeding. He looks at his wife a children, their faces somehow becoming more and more vagu BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the elements that made up my life were right there. And nothing new would ever happen. Like a little plastic boat that would sail on forever, without incident, until it finally sank, which would be a secret relief to all.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Kids laughing.    Camera skims across these handwritten w BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I ended that life and started this one. Now I dwell in a ugly world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present-day druggie Arctor returns to bed with his beer. JIM BARRIS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one will be totally soundless. There is another extremely loud gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris studies his silencer, perplexed.   Dogs bark again ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Barris. Y'know, you're supposed to be fixing the cephscope. Bob's lying in his bed right now thinking you're fixing his cephscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor lies in bed and writes in his notebook. The voice- over is different here: It's halting, as if he's composin and it's read with immediacy and anxiety. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I dwell in an ugly... disordered world. But this very disorder... permits... the... unpredictable to -- There's a knock on the door.    Arctor slips the notebook under the mattress. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Mumbling outside door.    Arctor fingers the gun under hi pillow. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Barris. The door opens.    Barris enters, shuffling, smiling, swe JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob.    I thought you'd be sleeping. Barris sits, uninvited, on the edge of Arctor's bed. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am here to inform you, Bob, that I have formulated an initial theory as to who may have systematically damaged your cephscope with malice and may do it again. Arctor waits.    Barris smiles a shit-eating smile. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D) (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the fuck would I screw up my own cephscope? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. You... (points at Arctor) ... are looking at the person who did it. (points at himself) That was my complete, intended statement, which I was not allowed to utter. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's my theory that I did it. Under post-hypnotic suggestion. With an amnesia block so I wouldn't remember BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Barris. Go fuck yourself. Arctor turns away from Barris.   Barris leans in close. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see, Bob, I've got the advanced, specialized, technical, electronic skills. I have access, because I live here. It all fits. (beat) What I can't figure out is my motive. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about, you're a fucked-up lunatic? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have been hired by secret forces. It could be as big as that, Bob. As huge as that. Arctor reaches under his bed frame and pulls out two tabs Substance D. He washes them down with beer, closes his ey BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor, Barris, and Luckman emerge from the house, bedraggled and bleary-eyed, and climb into Arctor's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor starts the car, begins to pull out of the driveway JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hold on, Bob. I forgot something. I forgot my antihistamine capsules. Arctor sighs, stops. Barris runs to the house.     Luckma Arctor wait in silence. Finally: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Barris does not have allergies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor, Barris, and Luckman drive along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls to a stop on a residential street. It's a a cruddy neighborhood. Apartment buildings. Graffiti. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys track down Andy and the hot scope. I'll pick you up in two hours. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are you off to? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropping in on a friend. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mysterious Bob Arctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor pulls into the parking lot, gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Kids voices in background.    Offhand Arctor reads the en BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While in Long Beach today I checked in on Kim, an addict acquaintance who lives with dealer Dan Blake. My intention was to get the latest on Blake, but also to strand Barris and Luckman down here long enough for the scanners to be installed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor knocks on an apartment door. Shuffling inside. chained door opens slightly. An eye peeks out. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, Kimberly. Bob Arctor. Kimberly unchains the door. She has a black eye and a spl lip. Her manner is listless. Arctor enters the apartment and Kimberly closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor looks around. The place is a shambles. There's bee a fight. The windows are broken, there's glass on the flo BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alone? KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and I had a fight and he split. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beat you up? KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God he didn't have his knife. His case-knife, which he now carries in a sheath on his belt. Kimberly drops back into a chair and stares blankly. KIMBERLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here, Bob? I'm bummed, I really am. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want him back? KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (listless shrug) Who knows? Arctor looks out the window at the street.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long can you go without? KIMBERLY Maybe. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you get it anywhere else? Y'know the name of Dan's supplier? Maybe you could deal directly. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. The sound of loud, irregular car pipes.   Kimberly stiffe KIMBERLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?    Fuck. Red '79 Torino? Arctor looks out and spots a red Torino pulling into the BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. A car door slams.    Kimberly shuffles to the front door triple locks it. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably has his case-knife with him. Y'know, he keeps it in a sheath on his belt now. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should call the police. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No phone. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim, he'll kill you. Kimberly shrugs and sits back down, staring blankly, hand clasped in her lap. Sound of running upstairs. A knock on the door turning to pounding. DAN (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the fucking door! KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (small voice) No.   I'm with someone.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DAN (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine!   I'll slash your tires! Sound of running downstairs. Kimberly rises, and she and Arctor watch out the window as Dan, a skinny, short-haire effeminate-looking guy, appears in the parking lot, crazi waving a knife in the air. DAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming up at Kimberly) I'll slash your tires, your fucking tires! And then I'll kill you! Dan begins slashing tires on Kimberly's old Dodge. This seems to wake Kimberly up. She shrieks, runs to the door and frantically begins unlocking it. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to stop him! I don't have insurance! Arctor grabs her, tries to hold her back. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tires aren't... KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling to get free) My tires! BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he wants you to do. KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs.   They have a phone!   Let me go! Kimberly fights loose of Arctor with manic energy. KIMBERLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unlocking the door) I'm calling the police. My tires! (out the door) One of them is new!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kimberly is scrambling down the stairs. She arrives at an apartment door and pounds on it. Arctor is right behind h

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KIMBERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open, please? Please? I need to call the police. Please let me call them. The door opens. An old man in tie and sweater stands ther Kimberly hurries past him, goes for the phone, and dials. BOB ARCTOR (to old man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor enters, closes the door and watches out the peepho KIMBERLY (on phone, crazily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, yeah, my boyfriend and me got into a fight because of these cowboy boots which were worth seven dollars. See, I said, they're mine, and he says, no, they're mine 'cause you gave them to me as a present. And I say but I bought them. Which makes them mine. Right? So he grabs 'em and I grab 'em, and I rip the backs of them with this can opener and... yes, I'll hold. Arctor glances at the old man, who's been quietly studyin him. An old woman in a print dress stands in the dining room doorway. Kimberly paces on hold, chews a fingernail. ARCTOR (to old man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must be bad on you. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes on all the time, them fighting, him saying he'll kill her. OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have gone back to Denver.   I told you that. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These terrible fights. On and on. Smashing things and screaming. And what's worse, every time -- OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, tell him about that.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time we go out, shopping or to mail a letter, we step in... what dogs leave. OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Dog doo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor drives on the freeway, deep in thought. Luckman's next to him. Barris is in back grinning in his dark shade BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dog shit. All that misery and that's what really upset them. Arctor chuckles.   The car is behind a crawling Safeway t ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to pass that truck, man. The humper's hardly moving. Arctor comes back into focus, picks up speed, passes the truck on the left. As he eases up on the gas, the pedal falls to the floor. The car shoots forward at great speed LUCKMAN AND BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down! Arctor is panicked. The speedometer is registering eighty five, ninety, one hundred. Arctor reaches down, tries to fiddle with the gas peddle. The car is rocketing right fo a VW van chugging along. Barris and Luckman throw up thei hands. Arctor swerves to the left of the van at the last minute. They pass it, but a fast moving Corvette had been about to pass in that lane. It honks, its brakes screech. LUCKMAN AND BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (top of their lungs) What the fuck?! What are you doing?! Luckman grabs at the ignition key, and turns it off. Arct shifts into neutral, the car begins to slow, and he maneuvers it onto the shoulder. The Corvette shoots by, l on it's horn, continues to do so until it's long gone dow the freeway. The three guys just sit in the car, hearts pounding. The VW van passes and honks its VW horn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened, Bob? They all look down at the still-depressed gas pedal. Safeway truck passes and sounds its own basso horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor, Barris, and Luckman are looking under the hood. White smoke drifts from the oil caps. Water fizzles from overflow spout of the radiator. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The linkage from the pedal to the carb fell apart. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't this locking ring hold the nut in place? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idle screw has been turned all the way out. So when the linkage parted, the override went up instead of down. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could it screw itself all the way out like that accidentally? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A special tool would be needed. A couple, in fact. I have the tools to fix this, but back at the house. Is Barris saying he did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor looks over at Barris. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we'll have to get to gas station and borrow tools from them. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, did this happen by accident or was it done deliberately? Like the cephscope. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still grinning) It's hard to say. (glances over at Arctor) You should've cut the ignition as soon as you realized what happened.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a second I couldn't figure it out. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning and lashing out with bost fists) MOTHERFUCKER! Somebody did this intentionally! They fucking almost killed us! Barris pulls out a snuffbox, removies a few tabs of Death and swallows them. He passes the snuffbox to Luckman, who takes a few with a shaky hand, then passes the box to Arctor. Arctor hands it back to Barris without taking any BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) Maybe this is what's fucking us up, messing up our brains. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dope can't screw up a carb-idle adjustment, my friend. (holds box out to Arctor) You'd better take at least three of these. They're primo, but mild. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the fucking snuffbox away! Barris smiles, puts it away. Arctor tries to focus back o the engine. He sways lightheadedly and supports himself against the car. The hot sun beats down on the back of hi head. Cars whiz by, the traffic noises intensified. He hears singing, quiet at first, but soon overwhelming. It' awful, discordant. He looks at Luckman and Barris, silhouetted against the sun. Luckman says something, but Arctor can't make it out over the singing and the traffic noise. An awful smell permeates the air. Arctor sniffs at it. His face contorts. He feels nauseated, shuts his eyes ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible above singing) Hey, do you smell something, man?   A clue? Some engine smell that -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes suddenly wide) Dog shit! Do you smell dog shit?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing Arctor) No. (to Barris) Were there any psychedelics in that dope? Barris smiles and shakes his head.   Arctor studies the engine, sniffs it. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an illusion, right? There's no dog shit smell. How could there be dog shit in the eng... He spots ugly, dark brown stains around the motorblock. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freaked) Dog shit! Dog shit! (trying to focus) Oil. Spilled oil. Thrown oil. That's all. Maybe a leaky head gasket. Arctor reaches down to touch the dark stain.    His hand back in revulsion. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dog shit!   Fuck! It is dog shit! Now he looks around the engine and sees it everywhere: al over the block, on the wires, on the fire wall. He looks up, sees it smeared on the soundproofing under the hood. The smell is overwhelming. He lurches away from the car, shuts his eyes, staggers. Luckman grabs Arctor's arm. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you're getting a flashback. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Free theater tickets. Luckman guides Arctor to the driver's seat, sits him down ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just take it easy. Nobody got killed and now we're warned. It's okay. It's okay. Everything's okay. Arctor closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kimberly walks, catatonic and terribly bruised. Dan pops and stabs her repeatedly. She falls onto a big wet pile o dog shit. Barris appears in an apartment window, waving. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob, want a lump of dog shit?   To chew on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor opens his eyes fast. Barris, looking on compassionately, squats next to him outside the car. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Jim?   What'd you say? Barris begins to laugh and laugh. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (punches Barris on the back) Leave him alone, man. Fuck off. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luckman) What did Barris say just now? What the hell exactly did he just say? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. I can't figure out half the things he lays on people. Arctor again looks at Barris.   He is smiling sweetly. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goddamn Barris! I know you did it, screwed over the cephscope and now my car! You kinky freak mother bastard! The smell of dog shit is becoming overwhelming again. Arctor tries not to vomit. His head swims. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Bob. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's him, man. I know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't make any sense.      He'd have snuffed himself too. Barris nods in agreement. He smiles again. Now there's do shit coating Barris's teeth. Arctor throws up on the dashboard, rests his head in his hands ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was in those tabs you gave us? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I took some too. And so did you. Didn't give us a bad trip. Besides it was so soon. Your stomach can't even absorb -- Arctor's head jerks up to face Barris. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: YOU FUCKING POISONED ME
dialogues.text: Barris and Luckman look at Arctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tow truck is parked in front of the car. The three guys are inside, Arctor at the wheel, Barris and Luckman in ba A mechanic closes up the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three drive along in silence.      Arctor is pale, bu back in control. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what's been going on back at the house. Arctor glances at Luckman in the rearview mirror. ERNIE LUCKMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this proves, Bob, that somebody is out to burn you real bad. I just hope the house is still there when we get back. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't worry too much about that, gents. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Barris, they may have ripped off everything we got, or stomped all our animals, or -- JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I left a little surprise for anyone entering the house. An electronic surprise, if you will. Arctor shifts his glance in the rearview mirror to Barris BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of surprise? It's my house, Jim, you can't start rigging up -- JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy.   Be cool. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what is it? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the front door is opened, my tape recorder starts recording. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've told me. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they come in the window or through the back door? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To increase the chance of them making their entry via the front door, I providentially left it unlocked. They drive in silence. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're not going to expect it to be unlocked, so they'll go in the window. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I put a note on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're jiving me. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fucking jiving us or not?   I can't tell with you, man. Is he jiving us or not, Bob? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see when we get back. If there's a note on the door and it's unlocked, we'll know he's not jiving us. More silence. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they'd probably take the note down and lock the door after vandalizing and robbing us. So we'll never know. It's that gray area again. Damn it! JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm kidding, guys! Only a psychotic would leave the front door open with a note on it. Silence. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you write on the note, Jim? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote: "Donna, come on in, the door's unlocked. We..." The note's to Donna. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did do that. He really did it. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, we'll know who's been messing with us, Bob. And that is of prime importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to the house. The three guys get out. A piece of paper is tacked to the door. It reads: "Donna co on inside; door's unlocked. We've gone to Long Beach for day to purchase a stolen cephscope."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Barris. Arctor turns the knob. It's unlocked. He looks at Barris and shakes his head. Barris grins, shrugs. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris studies the room. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. Everything is exactly as we left it. They're very clever. Barris pulls his .22 from the top of the bookshelf.    Th animals appear, clamoring to be fed. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Barris, I can see you're right. There was definitely someone here. You see, the scrupulous covering-over of all signs they otherwise would've left testifies to their -- (farts, heads into kitchen) Barris, you're one paranoid fuck. Barris continues to search the room, gun drawn. Arctor watches him intently, trying to appear uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Kids voices.   We scan across the following entry. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange how, now and then, paranoia can link up with reality. A hand turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris studies a full ashtray on the coffee table. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this! Arctor and Luckman, who has emerged from the kitchen with beer, approach the ashtray. Luckman holds his hand over i ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still-hot butt. It sure is.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arctor massages the bridge of his nose.     Then, trying best to play dumb: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, who was here? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, this is what's hot. (reaches into ashtray, pulls out roach) They lit a joint. (looking around) But what'd they do? What the fuck did they do? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That roach may not be a slip-up. Maybe they were here specifically to plant dope, then phone in a tip later. Maybe there's dope planted all over this house. We're going to have to go through and get this place clean. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check the wall sockets.   You take apart the tv and stereo. Luckman grabs a screwdriver.    Barris raises his head sa JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. If they see us scrambling around before the raid -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What raid? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- then we can't allege, even though it's true, that we didn't know the dope was there. Maybe that, too, is part of their ingenious plan. Luckman throws down the screwdriver as if it's red hot. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fucked! We can't do anything! BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you forget about the recorder, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. The tape should be extremely informational at this point. (pulls it from under couch) Well, it probably wouldn't ultimately have proven that important. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget to turn it on, did you? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The first thing they did upon entering was switch it to "off". ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's off?    Fuck! Those fuckers. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made their move swiftly, before so much as an inch of tape pasesd through the recording head. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?    Now what the fuck do we do? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Bob, there is one thing you could do, although it would take time. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell the house? Barris nods gravely. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anybody know a good realtor? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an acquaintance in the field. Barris and Luckman look at Arctor. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should probably act fast, man. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know how fast they're gonna swoop down on us. Arctor studies Barris and Luckman, their anxious eyes bor into him. He sways, gets confused, begins to buy Barris's scenario.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What reason should we give for selling? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can't tell the truth. We need a shuck. Barris, what's a good shuck? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just flat out say there's narcotics planted all over the place and since we don't know where, we decided to move out and let the new owner get busted instead of us. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't think we can afford to be that up front. Bob, you say you got a job transfer. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, though? Where the fuck to? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleveland. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
