dialogues.text: I say we tell them the truth. In fact, we can put an ad in the Times: "Modern, three bedroom tract house, two bathrooms for easy flushing, with high grade dope stashed in all rooms." It's a selling point. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they'd be calling asking what kind of dope, and we don't know. Man! JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or how much. Prospective buyers might inquire about the quantity. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slumps back on the couch) They appear to have us. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, this is awful! Donna appears from one of the bedrooms, rumpled and sleep

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I came in, like the note said.   I waited for you for awhile, then I crashed. Why are you guys yelling? The three guys look at each other. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you smoke a joint? Before you crashed? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Otherwise I can't sleep. You shouldn't leave your place unlocked like that. You could get ripped off and it would be your own fault. That's the main reason I came in when I saw the note. Somebody ought to be here if the place is unlocked with a note on it. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been here? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you could've taken down the note, locked the door, and left. Donna looks at Luckman, trying to figure out what he just said, then back to Arctor. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approximately thirty-eight minutes. Hey, Bob, I got that wolf book, if you want to see it. It's got a lot of heavy shit in it. Barris falls back into a ratty easy chair. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is only heavy and none else; heavy that leads to the grave. For everyone and everything. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say you were selling the house? Or was that me dreaming? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I hope it was you dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scramble-suited Hank is unrolling a floor plan labeled "Arctor's House" in front of scramble-suited Fred. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are the locations of the eight scanners. We transmit to a safe house down the block from Arctor's. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I do playback? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And we use also use it for playback on five other houses. So you'll be bumping into other undercover people. Always wear your scramble suit. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make note of the scanner locations. If they need servicing, you can take care of it while you're at Arctor's. As long as nobody's around. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to edit myself out, so you won't see who's fixing the scanners. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Although we assume you're Barris, or Luckman, or Freck, or Arctor or Donna Hawthorne -- FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (computerized chuckle) Donna? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't edit yourself from all tapes, or we'll deduce who you are by process of elimination. Leave yourself in in places. Be creative. Have fun. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will help greatly in determining what the hell Arctor's up to. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know he's up to anything. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got more recent information. There is no doubt any longer: Arctor's a phony, a three dollar bill. So keep on him until we have enough to arrest him and make it stick. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he's high up in Death distribution? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we think isn't of any importance to you. You report; we evaluate. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Arctor is doomed if he's up to anything. And I have a hunch from what you say that he is. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have a case on him soon. Then we can seize his house. I think you'd like it. It's rundown and dirty, but it's big. Nice yard. The installation crew reported it has excellent possibilities. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the living room gives a view of the intersection, so passing vehicles could be graphed and... but Burt What's-his-face, who headed the crew, felt that it'd been allowed to deteriorate so badly that -- FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deteriorate in what way? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof's perfect. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior and exterior paint.    The condition of the floors. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.    It's all fine. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you recommend we acquire it after Arctor's arrested and loses title? Fred just stares at Hank, who holds his pen at the ready. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no opinion. Fred rises to leave. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not splitting yet.     You have to report to room 203. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, if this is about the Lion's Club speech, I've already explained -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is something different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is all white, with steel fixtures, steel chairs, a steel desk. Fred is being interviewed by two sheriff's deputies in full uniform with medical stripes. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are Officer Fred? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you take Substance D? Fred is about to respond. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is moot, because it is taken for granted that in your work you are required to.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't answer. Not that it's incriminating, but it's simply moot. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, about the Lion's Club -- MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What this testing session is about stems from a departmental survey showing that several undercover agents have been admitted to Neural Aphasia clinics in the last month. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're aware that Substance D is highly addictive, are you not? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't answer that. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm an addict? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether or whether not you are an addict is not a prime issue, as a blocking agent is expected from the Army Chemical Warfare Division within the next five years. What these tests pertain to is -- MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's begin with the Set-Ground Test. Shall we? Medical Technician #1 holds up a card with a geometric diagram printed on it. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within these apparently meaningless lines is a familiar object that we all would recognize. You are to tell me what the object is and... Fred studies the diagram searching for some recognizable shape. There is nothing discernible in the diagram. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... point to it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In many of those taking Substance D, a split between the right hemisphere and the left hemisphere occurs. There is a loss of proper gestalting, which is a defect within both the percept and the cognitive systems. Fred continues to study the diagram. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see the form here, Fred? We need an answer. There is a time limit. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) I see a Coke bottle, I guess. The two technicians exchange glances. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soda pop bottle is correct. Medical Technician #1 puts down the card and makes a note his clipboard. He holds up another card. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this about the Lion's Club speech? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting cross-chatter, Fred? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting what? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the hemispheres. Cross- chatter. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's damage to the left hemisphere, where the linguistic skills are normally located, then sometimes the right hemisphere will fill in. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the best of its limited abilities. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm getting that.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoughts not your own, perhaps? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if another person were thinking? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreign words you don't understand? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll keep your eyes open for anything like this, won't you? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.     Now what do you see here? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheep. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us the sheep, Fred. Fred points. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impairment in set-background discrimination gets you into a heap of trouble -- instead of no forms, you actually perceive faulty forms. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forms that aren't there. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like dog shit, for example. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, what did you say? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Fred, what? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I'm guessing it's not a sheep. But was I close at least? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a Rorshach, Fred. There is only one right answer. In this case it's a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what?    What did you say it is? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dog. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   How can you tell? The technician turns over the card, showing the isolated outline of a greyhound on the other side. FRED (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I see it now. What does it mean that I saw a sheep? Does it mean that I'm crazy? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy isn't a psychiatric diagnosis, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck drives along in great spirits. He giggles and plots CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay okay okay. So I go to Barris, "Hey, Barris, I bought a methedrine plant today," and he goes... (childish Barris impersonation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Methedrine is a benny, like speed, la la la. It's made synthetically in a lab la la la. It isn't organic like pot. There's no such thing as a methedrine plant, like there is a pot plant." Then I go... (big punchline)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I meant I inherited forty thousand dollars from an uncle and purchased a plant in this guy's garage where he makes meth. It's a factory. Plant in that sense... ' Okay okay, I don't have the phrasing exactly yet, but when I lay this on Barris, man, I'm going to get him so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor and Barris, in greasy clothes, are in the driveway working on Arctor's car. Freck pulls up, gets out of his and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jim, I bought a meth plant today. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big a plant? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused as to how to proceed) Um, well... like, what do you mean? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you pay, Freck? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, about ten bucks. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim could've gotten it for you cheaper. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're practically giving meth plants away. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a whole fucking garage! A factory! It turns out a million pills a day! JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) All that for ten bucks? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's it located, Freck? CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not around here. Hey, fuck it, you guys. Freck leans against the house and pulls out a cigarette. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Barris) What about the carb?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bent choke shaft. The whole carb needs to be rebuilt. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it bent? Barris shrugs.    Luckman emerges from the house. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I phoned and they're checking to see what a rebuilt carb will set you back. Hey, Freck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luckman) Freck bought a meth plant today. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.    How big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arctor) You could put a four barrel on instead of a two, while you're at it. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would idle too high. And it wouldn't upshift. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idling jets could be replaced with smaller jets. And he could watch his rpms with a tach. Usually just backing off the gas pedal causes it to upshift if the automatic linkage doesn't do it. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he tromped down heavy on the step- down passing gear to get a lot of torque suddenly on the freeway, it'd downshift and rev up so high it'd blow the whole engine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tach needle would jump and he'd back off. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While passing a big semi? He'd have to blow the engine up or he'd never get around what he was trying to pass. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momentum would carry him past. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about uphill? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this car weigh, Bob? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a thousand pounds. Freck, who has been watching this exchange, catches Arcto wink at Luckman. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're right then. It wouldn't have much interia mass. (calculating on a pad) A thousand pounds traveling eighty miles an hour -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a thousand pounds with passengers, a full tank of gas, and a carton of bricks in the trunk. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many passengers, Bob? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's six in the back and six -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Eleven in the back and the driver alone up front. The extra weight is in the back so it doesn't fishtail.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This car fishtails? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you get eleven people in back. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be better, then, to have two three hundred pound bags of sand in the trunk. Then the passengers could be distributed more comfortably. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about one six hundred pound bag of gold, Jim? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you bastards wouldn't rappity-rap on like a bunch of speed freaks, I could complete my computations and tell you how this car with its weight would handle a four barrel carb. So shut the fuck up, you assholes! Luckman stares at Barris, pulls a book from his back pock ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to read to you now, Barris. (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He to whom it is given to see Christ more real than any other reality... JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? As Luckman reads, he walks menacingly toward Barris, who backs away. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...than any other reality in the World, Christ everywhere present and everywhere growing more great, Christ the final determination and plasmatic Principle of the Universe --" BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, Luckman? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teilhard de Chardin. "... that man indeed lives in a zone where no multiplicity can distress him and which is nevertheless the most active workshop of universal fulfillment."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Luckman closes the book. He has backed Barris against the wall of the house. Freck tries to get in between them. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool it, you guys. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the way, Freck. I'm going to coldcock Barris into tomorrow for talking to his betters like that. Luckman brings back his arm to punch Barris.    Barris bl in terror and runs crazily for the house. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear the phone ringing about the carb. I'll get it. They watch him go. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just kidding. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he comes back with his gun and silencer? Arctor and Luckman look dismissively at Freck, and go bac under the hood of the car. Freck stands nervously by his car, shifting from foot to foot, ready for a quick getawa CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm splitting. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, stay, man, you're a brother. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm cutting out. Barris emerges tentatively from the house, carrying a ham JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a wrong number, man. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's the hammer for, Jimmy-Boy? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To fix the engine. What else?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I would bring it with me, since I was indoors and noticed it. Freck watches this exchange.    He anxiously climbs in hi CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna split. I'll see you guys. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most dangerous kind of person is one who's afraid of his own shadow. Freck's eyes widen at this statement.    He drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck drives along, sweating. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Bob mean me afraid of my own shadow? But that was turning into a super-bummer. Where's the chicken into not wanting to be around that? Everything's changing, man. Used to be cool to hang out. Now its totally dark. Frank slips in his 8-track of Janis Joplin singing "All i Loneliness." He cries as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furniture has been removed from the lawn. Freck pulls into the driveway and heads to the house. He knocks on th door, waits, sniffling. He knocks again. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry! Jerry! Let me in, man, I'm truly bummed! I wanna talk! A couple of hippies on the stoop next door watch Freck. HEAD #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jerry's gone. Freck looks over blankly at the hippy.    Then it registe CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! I can't believe I forgot Jerry's dead. What is wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEAD #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not dead, man. He's in the Number Three Federal Clinic. Freck lets this register.   He starts to cry again. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, I can't believe I forgot Jerry's not dead. What is wrong with me? Freck hurries to his car, speeds down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor, Luckman, and Barris lounge around, stoned.     Ar seems relaxed, reclining on the couch and glancing discreetly at the hidden holo-scanner. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem mellow, Bob. Having to spend a hundred bucks on a new carb wouldn't make me mellow. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cruise the streets until I come across an Olds, then unbolt the carb. Like everyone else I know. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially Donna. That chick steals everything she can carry. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a Donna story. One day she put a quarter in a stamp machine and it kept spitting out stamps, till she had like eighteen thousand stamps. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what individual price per stamp? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen cents per individual stamp. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's twenty-seven hundred dollars, if my arithmetic is correct. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so what's Donna gonna do with so many stamps? She can barely write...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arctor smiles as he watches Luckman and Barris. Their chatter continues, but goes under as we hear Arctor's V.O BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scanners will have miles of this tripped-out garbage. But it's not the stuff that happens while I'm here that matters. It's what goes on while I'm gone. So I'll split. Then I'll see what these three clowns are up to. We again focus on Luckman and Barris's conversation. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she ripped off the whole stamp machine and remounted it, like, somewhere where the postal authorities wouldn't spot it and... Back to Arctor, as his expression shifts to anxious. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I see some awful truth about the people I care about on these tapes? What if I see Donna climbing in the window and ripping me off, or destroying my stuff? Or some weird, nightmarish world beyond the mirror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room has a monochromatic, dream-like quality t it. Suddenly Donna crawls in on all fours. There is an no human blankness to her face. She sticks her head into the dog's bowl and eats greedily, making slurping noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor lurches out of his fantasy, freaked out. Luckman a Barris don't notice. They're still jabbering away. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize our taxes were raised by her stealing those stamps? It's one thing to steal auto parts, but when you steal from Uncle Sam -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out to score some beans. Luckman, is your Falcon running?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, lying) No.   I don't think so. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder, Bob, if you can handle my car? By that mean there are -- ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, Barris. It's an ordinary six cylinder. The parking lot jockeys park it all the time, for God's sake. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are certain secret devices which have been incorporated -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that it has certain secret -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. If I tried to drive your car, I'd press the wrong button and float up over the greater L.A. area. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you appreciate my position. Arctor exits. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fucked, Barris. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred sits in a cubicle and stares at a holo-monitor On it Barris winds a string around the bowl of a hash pipe whil Luckman watches tv and stuffs his face from a tv dinner. hear other tapes being played in other cubicles: stoned conversations; screaming; high-pitched fast-forward squea Another scramble suit walks by Fred's cubicle and glances the monitor. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're allowed to fast forward through the dull stuff, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would if I could, but this is live. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment, chuckling) You call that living? Fred chuckles perfunctorily.   Scramble Suit #1 leaves. continues to watch. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full of food) Fucking McDonaldburger commercials. Suddenly Luckman gags, jumps to his feet, turns to Barris signaling wildly. He staggers around, choking. Barris watches him blankly. Luckman lurches to the kitchen. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus fuck!   Barris! We see Luckman on the kitchen holo-scanner knocking thing over, grabbing a glass from the counter and trying to fil with water. On the living room monitor, Barris camly continues to wrap string around his hash pipe. FRED (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping to his feet) Barris?! Barris!! Luckman gives up on the water and begins hurling pots and plates at the kitchen walls trying to attract Barris's attention. Barris, in the living room, does not respond. All at once, Luckman falls to the kitchen floor unconscio In the living room, Barris smiles a little smile. Fred watches, paralyzed. Barris casually rises and strolls int the kitchen. He studies Luckman spread out on the floor. He looks at the dishes and pots scattered about. Then, suddenly, he rips off his sunglasses in a faux panic, working himself up for the frantic 911 phone call. His ey widen in horror, he flaps his arms helplessly, runs back forth until he starts to pant, then dials the phone. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator, I need, I'm not sure, is it called the inhalator squad or the resuscitation squad? OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone unable to breathe, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, I believe, cardiac arrest. Either that or involuntary aspiration of a bolus within the -- OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the address, sir? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The address, the address.      let's see... FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ!    Just -- Luckman heaves violently on the floor. He thrashes around throws up the material in his throat, and opens his eyes. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you. No assistance is needed after all. Good morrow. Barris hangs up. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, Ernst? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must've gagged. Did I pass out? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. You did go into an altered state of consciousness for a few seconds. Probably an alpha state. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. I shit myself. Luckman stands, unsteadily. Fred relaxes, sits back down his console. Luckman splashes himself with tap water. ERNIE LUCKMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing while I was lying there, jacking off? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw me on the phone, summoning the paramedics. I moved into action immedi -- ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor walks home, deep in thought. A MG speeds by, makes screeching u-turn, pulls up beside Arctor, honks it's hor Arctor squints inside. It's Donna. He opens the passenger door, gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I scare you? Heh heh. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did a freaky number, not like a fantasy trip, but... So I'm kinda -- DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your stuff. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My stuff? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Death. Donna screeches off too fast, weaves, tailgates a Coke tr BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Barris. You know how he kills you? He doesn't. He waits until a situation arises where you die, and he just sits there. In fact he sets you up to die. I don't know how exactl -- DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have the money? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the money right now. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Yeah. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like Barris, and I don't trust him. He's crazy. And you're crazy when you're around him. You're crazy right now.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, I know I can count on you to tell me if I'm getting weird or crazy or like that. Okay? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you wanna take me to a concert at Anaheim Stadium next weekend? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on.     Yeah. That sounds -- DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna bring some really oily hash and get really loaded. But you have to wear something neat, not those funky clothes you sometimes wear. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wear whatever you say. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking us to my place. And you do have the money and you'll give it to me. Then we'll drop a few of the tabs and kick back. Maybe you could buy a fifth of Southern Comfort and we could get bombed as well. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow.   That sounds good. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what would be cool tonight, is to go to the Torrance Drive-in. They're showing all eleven Planet of the Apes movies. From 7:30 to 8:00 tomorrow morning. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can a drive-in show movies in the morning? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen all the Ape movies in years. And the last one for longer than that, the one where they reveal (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: all the famous guys in history, like Nero and Lincoln, were secretly apes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. The door unlocks, light from the hall spills i Donna enters, flips on the light. There's a trail of newspapers on the floor. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay on the newspaper. I just had the rug shampooed. Arctor enters and stands on a square of newspaper. He loo around. The place is cluttered with piles of stuff BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever throw anything away? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday I'm gonna get married and I'm going to need all this stuff. When you get married, you need everything there is. Donna slips out of her leather jacket, tosses it on a pil jackets, and pads into the kitchen. Arctor follows her, tiptoeing along the paper. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much of what you've got did you buy and how much did you steal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy?   What do you mean "buy"? Donna opens a cabinet, reaches in back, pulls out several plastic bags of pills. She lays them on the counter, open a drawer, pulls out a pipe and some hash, sits at the tab and fills the pipe. Arctor lays money on the table. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like when you buy dope. Like a dope deal. When I mean by "buy" is an extension into the greater world of business transactions of what we have present now, with us, as dope deals.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I see what you're saying. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like when you rip off those Coca-Cola truck you tailgate. That's stealing. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     It's a form of barter. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, look, you're gonna get caught, and if you got drugs in your car when they catch you, there's nothing I can do to protect you then. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You protect me? What are you talking about? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.     I just... Please take care. Donna lights the pipe. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coca-Cola company is a capitalist monopoly. No one else can make it but them. That's fucking wrong. (beat) C'mere, I'll supercharge you. Arctor sits down at the table. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, cool. Donna walks over to him, puffing the hash pipe to keep it alive. She bends over him and Arctor opens his mouth. She exhales long and forcefully into his mouth. This is as cl as these two get to sex. Arctor's eyes go soft as he look up at Donna. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Donna. Donna looks down at him. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can dig it, you being in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donna grins, sits down and takes a hit from the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna and Arctor are stoned on the couch in the dim room. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Donna, man, do you like cats? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping little things. Moving along about a foot above the ground. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   On the ground. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drippy.    Behind furniture. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little spring flowers, then? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Little spring flowers. With yellow in them. That first come up. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before.    Before anyone. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Before anyone stomps on them and they're gone. Arctor's eyes get wet. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know me exactly, Donna. You can read me. No one knows me but you. Donna draws on the pipe, but it's out. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more. Her smile disappears. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, can I put my arm around you.   I want to hold you, okay? Donna's stoned eyes suddenly widen. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're too ugly. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Look, I snort a lot of coke; I have to be super careful because I snort a lot of coke. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugly?   Fuck you, Donna. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave my body alone. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting on his shoes) Sure. Yeah. You better believe it. Arctor rises, disappears into the kitchen. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after) I don't like people to grope my body! (talking to herself) I have to watch out for that because I do so much coke. Someday I'm gonna go over the Canadian border with four pounds of coke in my snatch. I'll say I'm a Catholic and a virgin. Arctor passes through the room with his bags of Death. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking off. He heads for the door.   Donna tries to rise, confused an half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have your car. I'll drive you, man. (looks for her shoes) But you can see why I have to protect my snatch -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too stoned to drive and you never let anyone else drive that little roller skate of yours. She jerks upright and glares wildly at him. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) That's because no one else can fucking drive my car! Nobody else ever gets it right, no man especially! Driving or anything else! Listen, you had your hands down into my -- Arctor is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor hurries through the darkness. Donna pants behind h trying to catch up. She does. Arctor keeps walking. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dreadfully sorry I hurt your feelings. Okay? I was out of it. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Too ugly. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get really spaced. You wanna come back? Or what? You wanna go to the drive-in? What about the Southern Comfort? C'mon, I'm sorry. Arctor stops, stares off for a while.   Donna watches, wa BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. They turn and head back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sure is good hash though, huh? They walk in silence. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm going to do someday, Bob? I'm going to move north to Oregon and live in the snow. Have a little house and a vegetable garden. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to save up for that. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing up shyly) He'll get me that. What's-his-name. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharing a secret) Mr. Right. He'll drive an Aston- Martin and take me north in it. And that's where the little old fashioned house will be in the snow. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure this'll happen? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the cards. A heaviness descends upon Arctor.    He stops.   Donna st BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, can I go with you? To Oregon? When you do take off finally? Donna smiles up at Arctor. She gently shakes her head "no He studies her. Her answer will never change. He shivers. Donna takes Arctor's hand, squeezes it, holds it. Her tou fills him. After a moment, Donna lets her hand drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor enters the dimly lit bedroom followed by Connie, a skinny girl with hollow eyes and a flat affect. He sifts through his dresser drawer as she hovers behind him. Fina he pulls out a baggie with some pills in it. Throughout, hear stoned conversation coming from another room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go. CONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. Connie stuffs the baggie into her purse. She sits on the bed and begins to unceremoniously undress. When her blous comes off, we see needle tracks and bruises on her arms. She pulls a comb from her purse and listlessly combs her lank hair. She drops the hand holding the comb and begins to nod. Arctor looks at the tracks, at the pimple on her cheek. Connie wakes up, sort of, and starts combing again CONNIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Do you have a toothbrush I can use. Aw screw it -- teeth are teeth. I'll brush 'em. You gotta ... Connie drones on, but her voice has become so quiet it ca be heard. Arctor watches her lips work soundlessly. Finally her voice becomes audible again. CONNIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are those guys rattling on and on out there? Jabber-jaws. They live here with you, I guess. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of them do. Connie fixes her dead eyes on Arctor. CONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're queer? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to be. That's why I've arranged this transaction with you. CONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose I'm about to find out. Connie removes her bra and her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are off. The off-screen conversation has stopp Instead we hear static from a signed-off tv station. Arct is in bed with Connie. Both are naked and partially under covers. Connie lies rigidly on her back, arms straight do by her sides. She snores. Arctor moves in and out of

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: consciousness. He opens his eyes, groggily orients himsel glances over at the woman next to him. It's Donna. He bolts upright, studies her face. It's still Donna. He fumbles for the switch on the night table lamp and knocks to the floor. The woman next to him sleeps on. He watches her face. Gradually it begins to turn back into Connie. Arctor drops onto his back and looks at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred sits in his cubicle monitoring the scanners. On one scanner Barris sits in the living room reading a book abo mushrooms. After a moment, he lays the book face down on coffee table and leaves the house. Fred watches the empty living room. He presses the fast forward button. The sunlight coming in through the living room window shifts the day speeds by. The living room door opens. Fred slows the tape to normal speed. Barris is back at the couch wit a brown bag. He dumps several mushrooms onto the table, compares them with illustrations in the book. Finally, he puts one aside, throws the rest in the bag, crumbles the mushroom, and fills capsules. He dials the phone. An LED Fred's console indicates the phone number dialed. TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jim. TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the beard. Green shades. Leather pants. I met you at that happening at -- TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.    Yeah. That guy.    Jim. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, have I scored. Psylocybe Mexicana. A rare hallucinogenic mushroom used in South American mystery cults thousands of years ago. You fly, become invisible, understand the speech of animals -- TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truly?   How much?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Two other Scramble Suits walk by Fred's console. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five dollars a cap. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he peddling? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mushrooms he seems to have picked locally. SCRAMBLE SUIT #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain Amanita mushrooms contain toxins that act as red blood cell cracking agents. It takes two weeks to die, it's incalculably painful, and there's no antidote. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the statute violation? SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Misrepresentation in advertising. Both Scramble Suits laugh their computer laughs and disappear. Fred goes back to the monitors. The front door opens and Bob Arctor enters dejectedly. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Bob. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Barris) Hi. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you make out with little Miss Big Tits? Barris chuckles. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Barris. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Barris. Arctor passes out of range of the scanner. After a moment he reappears on the scanner inside his bedroom. He shuts the door, removes the bags of tabs he scored from Donna, looks around the room, then settles on stuffing the bags the back of his dresser drawer. He heads out of the bedro

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: and reappears on the living room monitor.      He walks p Barris. Barris trails him casually JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I'm sorry if I offended you. Both disappear from the living room monitor and reappear the kitchen monitor. Arctor fills the coffee pot with wat BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Luckman? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left with your jack, so I assume he's off to knock over pay phones. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My axle jack? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, I have a sure fire way you could get into the pants of Little Miss Big Tits. For under one dollar. Fred fast forwards the tape. He stops. Barris and Arctor are now on the living room monitor. Arctor is fuming. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either you pay up your back rent or get to work fixing my godamn cephscope! JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. About that, Bob. I've already ordered resistors -- Fred fast-forwards again. Now Barris is on the living roo monitor reading about mushrooms and Arctor is on the moni in his bedroom, writing in his notebook. The phone rings the living room monitor. Barris picks up. JIM BARRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? TELEPHONE VOICE #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arctor? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Robert Arctor. Inside the Fred scramble suit we see Arctor's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TELEPHONE VOICE #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bother you, Mr. Arctor, but your check did not clear. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I've been meaning to call you, but I've had a severe bout of intestinal flu, with loss of body heat, pyloric spasms, cramps... In the monitor in his bedroom, Arctor continues to write his notebook, unaware. In his scramble suit at the consol Bob Arctor, is freaked out, and writes in the same notebo BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris portraying Arctor as coming off heroin. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just haven't been able to get it together to make that little twenty dollar check good, and frankly I don't intend to make it good. BOB ARCTOR (IN SCRAMBLE SUIT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? TELEPHONE VOICE #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me correctly. TELEPHONE VOICE #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arctor, those flu symptoms you describe... I think you're a -- JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think what you want. Turn out, tune out, and good-bye. Barris hangs up.   Fred checks the LED, picks up his phon FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a name and address on this. OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Englesohn Locksmith, 1343 Harbor in Anaheim, Loverboy. Fred hangs up. We move inside the suit to Arctor's troubl face. He writes in his notebook. The V.O. is disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris up to something: pretending to be me... writing rubber checks on my account... representing me as a heroin addict. BUT WHAT IS HE UP TO?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred paces. He passes a wall mirror, glances at his vague face. He moves closer to the mirror, studies himself. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor must've burned Barris pretty bad to deserve this display of malice. Scramble Suit #1 approaches Fred. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking, do you actually know these losers? Are you in among them? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I'm there. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to warn them about the mushrooms. Can you pass it on to them without faulting your cover? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I can lay it on that one. (indicates Arctor) Without him flashing on me. He's docile. SCRAMBLE SUIT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugly-looking, too. Scramble Suit #1 laughs.   Fred joins in wholeheartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred watches the monitors. Arctor's house is quiet. Barri and Luckman doze in the living room, the television tuned static. On another monitor, Arctor is sleeping in his bed with a woman. After a beat Fred notices the woman is Donn We move in close to Fred's ever-changing eyes. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can't be right. Arctor has never done it with Donna. Has he?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fred fast-rewinds the tape, switches it to play. Arctor i in bed having sex with Connie. Fred sighs a computerized sigh of relief and fast-forwards the tape. Arctor is now sleeping next to Connie. Fred watches for a moment. As he does the face of the sleeping woman transforms into Donna Fred freezes the frame. Then he enlarges the holographic image so it fills up the space previously occupied by all eight monitors. The image is now almost actual size. Fred rises and walks around the console into the projection ar It's as if he's entering Arctor's bedroom, or a slightly scaled down, frozen version of it. He approaches the sleeping couple, bends down and examines the face of the woman. It is clearly Donna. He stands in Arctor's bedroom for a while, confused and disoriented, tries to look at himself in Arctor's bureau mirror. Fred does not appear i the holographic reflection of the room. He shudders, returns to the console, brings up all eight monitors, and turns off the freeze-frame. On the bedroom monitor, Arcto awakens, and glances over at the woman sleeping next to h His eyes widen. He fumbles for the switch on the bedside lamp, knocks it over. He turns back and stares at the sleeping woman. As does Fred at the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A yellow cab pulls up.     Arctor emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plump old lady stands behind the counter.    Arctor ent OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir?   Good morning. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm here... The scene shifts to very slow motion. Everything grows quiet. Colors become saturated, as in a Raphael painting. FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ihr Instrumente freilich spottet mein/Mit Rad und Kammen, Walz' und Bugel:/Ich stand am Tor, ihr... The scene shifts back.     Maybe a hiccup's worth of time passed. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to pay for a check of mine the bank returned. It's twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   All-rightey. The old lady opens a metal file box and, after a moment's search, pulls out a check with a note clipped to it. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arctor, is it? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am Mr. Arctor. Nobody else is. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sir. That'll be twenty dollars. Arctor hands her a twenty dollar bill. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this, but by mistake I wrote the check on a closed account. The lady nods amiably as she writes something on the note BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, I'd appreciate if you'd tell your husband -- OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother Carl. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate if you'd tell your brother that I was distraught when he called and I apologize for that, too. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he said something about that, yes. She hands the bad check back to Arctor. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any extra charge? OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No extra charge. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was distraught because a friend of mine had just passed-on suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear. His business done, Arctor stands at the counter awkwardly BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He choked to death alone, in his room, on a piece of meat. No one heard him. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Mr. Arctor, more deaths happen from that than people realize. I read that if you're dining with a friend and he doesn't talk for a long time, you should ask him if he can, beacuse he may be strangling. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's true. Thanks.      And thanks about the check. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry about your friend. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.     He was the best friend I had. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dreadful. I'll tell Carl. And thank you for coming all the way down. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. And thank Mr. Englesohn for me. Thank you both so much. Arctor stands there.    The two just look at each other. BOB ARCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, thank you. Arctor backs out of the tiny shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor rides in the back with his open notebook and studi the returned check. He writes in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: We see Arctor writing the following words in the same handwriting as is on the check. The V.O. is tense.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect forgery. Barris has my handwriting down. How many checks has he written on my account? Evil genius bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor looks up, stares out the window, tries to focus. Something's bothering him. The stores speed by in a blur color. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I, Bob Arctor, wrote this check myself and just don't remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is on the pay phone outside the Shell station. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bother you again, ma'am, but I was just wondering what address do you have for that service call? OLD LADY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Mr. Arctor, I'll check. OLD MAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Arctor? OLD LADY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but Carl, don't say anything.   He came in just now -- OLD MAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him. OLD LADY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arctor? It says here it was in Santa Ana. On Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is stoned and on the phone in the crowded, smokey, noisy room. A blonde woman nibbles his ear. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I lost my ignition key. (pause) 34881 Main Street, Santa Ana...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor hangs up the pay phone.   He paces, trying to thin BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Arctor's the forger, not Barris! Not deliberately, but because his brain is slushed on dope. All their brains are... The busy intersection slows almost to a standstill. Color become saturated. Details seem momentous: A man gesturing in mid-conversation, a newspaper blowing down the street. FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Der wurme gleich' ich, der den Staub Durchwuhlt,/Den, wie er sich im Staube nahrend lebt,/Des Wandrers Tritt... Back to normal as a car passes with a faulty muffler. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... slushed and mutually interacting in a slushed way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor rides in the back. He stares out the window at the endless loop of McDonald's, Thriftys, 7-11's. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what is Arctor up to? Clearly the Sheriff's Office has some good reasons to focus their investigation on him. No doubt reasons I know nothing about. My job is to report, theirs to evaluate. Arctor lets his head fall back against the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab drops Arctor off. He heads up the newspaper-strew walk to the front door. He eyes the house and the grounds The house needs paint, a rain gutter is halfway dislodged The yard is overgrown. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking waste of a perfectly good house. A family could live here, for Christ's sake. (picks up newspapers) Oughta take it away from this fuck.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arctor arrives at the front door, tries to pull his house keys from his pocket without spilling the armful of newspapers. He succeeds, opens the door, enters the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a mess.    Arctor drops the papers on the fl BOB ARCTOR (for benefit of scanners)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody home, I guess. Arctor moves through the room in an almost studied way. There is something stilted about the way he intentionally avoids looking in the direction of the scanner.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: Kids playing in background. The camera glides across the following words as the dispassionate V.O. reads along. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does a scanner see? Does it see into the head? Into the heart? Does it see into me clearly or darkly? I hope clearly, because I can't any longer. I see only murk inside and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor rises and pulls a book from the shelf. It is The Picture Book of Sexual Love. He opens the book, revealing photo of a man nibbling a woman's breast. He positions himself so as to be best picked up by the living room scanner,then appears to read aloud from the book. We can that what he is reciting is not on the page. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any given man sees only a tiny portion of the total truth, and... Shift to slow motion.    Saturated colors.    Very quiet. FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weh! steck' ich in dem Kerker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck lays fresh sheets on his bed in his neat apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no problem how to kill yourself in the circles in which I hang. When life becomes more and more depressing as you watch those you know falling apart from drug use, just take a large quantity of reds. Freck places a bag of reds on the night table. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wash 'em down with a bottle of cheap wine. Freck pulls a bottle of Thunderbird from the counter of h kitchenette and places it next to the pills. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hard part is choosing the correct artifacts to be found on you by later archaeologists. So they know from which stratum you came and where your head was at when you did it. Freck pulls a copy of "The Fountainhead" from his book shelf, and places it face down and open on his bed. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be found with Ayn Rand's "The Fountainhead" open by my side to prove I have been a misunderstood superman rejected by the masses and so, in a sense, murdered by their scorn. Freck places a typewritten letter next to the book. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, an unfinished letter to Exxon protesting the cancellation of my gas credit card. That way I will indict the system and achieve something by my death. Over and above what the death itself achieves. Freck lies on the bed and readies himself for the suicide He unscrews the cap on the wine, tastes it, reconsiders. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps a connoisseur wine is in order on such an auspicious occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck drives, an expensive-looking bottle of wine on the seat next to him. He anxiously eyes the gas gauge on empt CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll soon be sorry, Exxon, you ever tangled with Charles B. Freck! Junior!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred sits in his scramble suit watching a holo-tape. In i Arctor is pulling a book from the shelf in his living roo and opening it. Fred zooms in to the title of the book. I is The Picture Book of Sexual Love. Fred zooms back out t take in the entire scene. Arctor recites, ostensibly from the book, in a creaky, stagy way. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any given man sees only a tiny portion of Weh! steck' ich in dem Kerker noch? Verfluchtes the total truth, and very often, in fact almost perpetually dumpfes Mauerloch... FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is he talking about? Fred glances at the other monitors. The only other activi is in Luckman's room, where Luckman lies snoring, sprawle his floor, a bag of reds by his side. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wo selbst das liebe Himmelschlicht he deliberately deceives trub durch gemalte Scheiben bricht! FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing head games with us.   He's shucking us. The fucker! Fred rises and paces in front of the console, keeping an on the monitors, trying to figure what Arctor is up to. O the other monitor, we see that Arctor's recitation has roused Luckman, who sits up groggily and listens to the o German-English rant. Luckman picks up an axe, heads to th bedroom door, and listens there intently. In the living room, Arctor has put down his book and is sifting through the pile of mail on the coffee table. He tosses a large piece of junk mail at the trash can. It misses and crashe against the wall. In his bedroom, Luckman hears the crash He stiffens suspiciously, sniffs the air, raises the axe, ready to tear into the other room and attack. In the livi room, Arctor reads a piece of mail.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regular voice) I'll be dipped. Luckman recognizes Arctor's voice, relaxes, puts down his axe, opens the bedroom door, and exits his bedroom. He appears on the living room monitor with Arctor. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, what's happening, Bob? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove by the Maylar Microdot Corporation building. Luckman casually drops into a chair across from Arctor. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shitting me. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the employees had evidently tracked the inventory out on the heel of his shoe. So they were all in the parking lot with many little magnifying glasses. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning) Any reward? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had a reward, but they lost that, too. It was a little tiny penny. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How large is the Maylar Microdot Corporation building? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathetic, soulless nitwits. Fred sighs, fast-forwards the tape. He watches on the met until an hour's worth of tape has passed. He switches bac to play. Arctor is across the room now, sprinkling food into a fish tank. Luckman is stretched out on the couch. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an inch high.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then how can you tell when you drive past it, if its only an inch? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a really big sign. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Fred fast forwards again for a long while, then puts the machine back on play. Now Luckman is on the floor, cleani some grass. Arctor sits on the couch strumming a guitar. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the sign look like? Fred fast forwards until five hours have past, then goes back to play. The living room is cloudy with smoke, as Luckman and Arctor pass a joint back and forth. ERNIE LUCKMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know how can you smuggle microdots into the U.S.? Barris told me. I'm not supposed to say, cause he's putting it in his book, "Simple Ways to Smuggle Objects into the U.S. and Out, Depending on Which Way You're Going." BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just tell me. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smuggle it with a shipment of dope. Like heroin. The microdots are so small no one would notice. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a decent idea. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barris had this other idea for smuggling dope. You know how the custom guys, they ask you to declare what you have? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you take a huge block of hash and you carve it in the shape of a man. Then you hollow out a little section and put a wind-up motor in. And a cassette tape. And just before it goes through customs, you wind it up and it walks up to the man, who says, "Do you have anything to declare?" and it says, "No, I don't," and keeps on walking. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put a solar battery in it, it could keep walking for years. Forever. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use of that? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine an Eskimo village. And this six foot block of hash worth... What would it be worth? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A billion dollars? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. Two billion. So these Eskimos are chewing hides when this six foot block of hash comes walking through the snow saying, "No, I don't" over and over again. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd wonder what it meant by that. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legends would spring up. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine telling your grandkids, "I saw with my own eyes a six foot block of hash appear and walk past, worth two billion dollars, saying, "No, I don't." His grandchildren would have him committed. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, see, legends build. So in a few centuries it would be, "In my forefathers' time, a ninety foot high block of extremely good quality (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afghanistan hash worth eight trillion dollars came at us dripping fire and screaming, "Die, Eskimo dogs!" And we fought and fought with it and finally killed it with our spears. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids wouldn't believe that either. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids never believe anything anymore. Fred's phone rings. It jerks him out of his focus on the monitor. He pauses the tape and picks up the phone. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, we've processed your tests. We need you to come back for the full battery. Tomorrow at three. Do you remember the room number? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... okay. TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 203. Are you all right, Fred? Any confusion? Difficulty identifying persons or objects? Does anything you see appear inverted or reversed? Any space-time or language disorientation? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, what?   I just... what exactly have you processed... that is, is this in regard to the Lion's Club speech? TELEPHONE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take all that up tomorrow, Fred. Dial tone. Fred hangs up and fast-forwards the tape. He watches as the tape whirs through the machine. He presses stop, the tape jerks to a halt. Fred breathes hard, although it comes through the grid sounding oddly mechanical. He pushes play. Luckman is cleaning grass on the floor. Barris is in the corner winding string. Arctor rubs his finger on the lip of a wine glass, making it hum

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this guy appeared on tv, claiming to be a world-famous imposter. He said he'd posed at one time or another as a great surgeon, a theoretical submolecular high-velocity particle research physicist, a Finnish novelist, a deposed president of Argentina... BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got away with it? Never got caught? ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, the guy never really posed as any of it. He only posed as a world- famous imposter. Turns out he just pushed a broom at Disneyland, until he read about this actual world-famous imposter, and he thought, I can pose as all those things, then he thought, hell, I'll just pose as an imposter. Save a lot of time, a lot easier. Made almost as much money as the real imposter with books and movie rights. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see imposters in our lives, now and then. But not posing as physicists. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narks, you mean. Yeah, I wonder what a nark looks like? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like asking what an imposter looks like. I asked a hash dealer who'd been busted once what the nark who busted him looked like -- JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looked just like us. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More so. The dealer dude told me the nark had longer hair than we do. I guess the moral is, stay away from guys who look like us. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narks give me the creeps.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could a guy do that is what I want to know, pose as a nark? LUCKMAN AND BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I'm spaced. Pose as a nark. ERNIE LUCKMAN

dialogues.speaker: POSE AS A NARK
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brains are scrambled today.      I better go crash. Fred freezes the tape.   He scribbles in notebook.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: Fred writes in a different handwriting now: choppy, backw slanted, crabbed. FRED (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posing as a nark. What does Arctor mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freck sits up in bed in his now electric yellow room, sipping magenta wine. The walls are dripping. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been burned. These are not reds, but rather some freaky psychedelic, the likes of which I have never seen. The wall across from Freck's bed parts with a sloshing sound, and an eight foot high creature with many eyes and ultra-hip clothing appears at his bedside, holding a scro CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. You're going to read me my sins, aren't you? The creature nods solemnly and unrolls the scroll. CHARLES FRECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's going to take a hundred thousand million hours, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CREATURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are no longer in the mundane universe. Your sins will be read to you ceaselessly throughout eternity. CHARLES FRECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know your fucking dealer, man. CREATURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from scroll) November 14, 1962, 3:08:23 pm: you did knowingly and with malice aforethought punch your baby sister Evelyn on the left side of the head when your mother was not looking. November 14, 1962, 3:08:27 pm: you did knowingly and with malice aforethought punch your baby sister on the left arm when your mother was not looking. November 14, 1962, 3:08:32 pm: you did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is finishing up mowing the lawn. He is intently focused on the task, but has done an erratic job: the lef side of the yard has been left almost completely unmowed. Arctor turns to enter the house. We see that the left sid of his face is completely unshaved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred is in the midst of a battery of tests being administered by two uniformed medical technicians who resemble the technicians who administered the previous tests, but are not the same. Fred's head rests in a contraption that divides his face in half, so his right e and left eye can be exposed to different projected images MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Fred, in rapid succession you will see a number of objects pass before first you left eye, then your right eye. At the same time, on the panel before you, outlines of these objects will appear. You are to match, by means of the punch pencil you hold in your hand, the outline with the object. These images will flash very quickly so don't hesitate too long. You will be scored for time as well as accuracy. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Technician #4 flips a lever, the panel in front of Fred lights up, and we see a wide array of outline drawings: a hammer, a shoe, a seagull, a camel, etc. Then in rapid succession, photographic images of these objects and othe flash before Fred's left eye. He tries to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, now with an eye patch over his left eye, faces a screen. On the table in front of him is a wide array of small objects: A toy boat, a die, a key, a marble, etc. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
