dialogues.text: Now, an image of a familiar object will be projected, you are to reach into the group of objects on the table in front of you, with your left hand -- and pick up the corresponding object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred is blindfolded, a box with hand-holes in front of hi MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next, you will reach into this box and touch the object inside with your left hand. After that you will be shown three objects visually. They will somewhat resemble each other and you will tell us which one most resembles the item you felt in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred sits with a pile of oddly shaped blocks, which he is attempting to fit into their corresponding holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred sits before a table on which are scattered a bunch o identical plastic birds and one plastic lion. Fred studie the table, finally picking up one of the plastic birds. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the different one. Medical Technician #4 makes a note on his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Fred, good. Let us process -- Fred looks up from the table at Medical Technician #3, wh is now Medical Technician #2 from the previous scene. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- these test results. And we'll get back to you within a couple of hours. Medical Technician #4 is now Medical Technician #1. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your cooperation, Fred. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.    Thank you all very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred walks hurriedly through the hall, past other Scrambl Suits and uniformed police personnel. He enters an office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank looks up from his desk. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, is that you? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, this is the informant who phoned in about Bob Arctor. Hank indicates Jim Barris, sitting against the wall, grinning crazily and fiddling with a paper clip. HANK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We challenged him to appear in person and he did. Do you know him? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. (to Barris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're James Barris, aren't you? Barris continues to grin, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His i.d. shows him to be, yes. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he want? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have evidence that Mr. Arctor is part of a large, secret covert organization, well-funded, with arsenals of weapons at their disposal, probably dedicated to the overthrow -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That part is speculation. We want to know what your firsthand evidence is. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in a mental hospital, Mr. Barris? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have not, sir, ever been in a -- FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign a sworn notarized statement regarding your evidence? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He already has, Fred. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My evidence, gentlemen, which I mostly don't have with me today, consits of tape recordings I have made of Robert Arctor's phone conversations. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this covert organization? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it to be political in nature, and against this country. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is Arctor's relationship to Substance D? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you examine my evidence, you will undoubtedly conclude that Substance D is produced by a foreign nation determined to overthrow the U.S., and (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JIM BARRIS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that Robert Arctor has his hands deep in the machinery of -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tells us the name of anyone else inside this organization? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Miss Donna Hawthorne. On various pretexts he goes over to her place and colludes with her regularly. Fred laughs his computerized laugh.      Barris laughs al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colludes?    What do you mean? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've followed him in my car, sir. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's his girl! HANK (to Fred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think there's nothing to this? FRED (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's look at his evidence. HANK (to Barris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring us your evidence. (to Fred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should send an officer with him to retrieve it. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one more thing. Mr. Arctor is addicted to Substance D. His mind is deranged now. He's become dangerous. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangerous. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already having episodes such as occur with brain damage from Substance D. Deterioration in the corpus callosum.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kind of unsupported speculation is worthless. We'll send an officer with you to collect your evidence. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sirs -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll arrange for an officer out of uniform, so it won't be conspicuous. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be murdered. Mr. Arctor is, as I say -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We appreciate your extreme risk, Mr. Barris. If your information is of significant value in obtaining a conviction, then naturally -- JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why I'm doing this. The man is sick. Brain damaged from Substance D. The reason I am here -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't care why you're here. We only care if your evidence amounts to anything. The rest is your problem. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sirs. Thank you very much. Barris grins and nods and sweats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred enters. Medical Technician #1 and Medical Technician #2 look up from their desks. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, is that you? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat, then. Fred sits in a chair against the wall. The technicians go back to their paper work. Fred waits stiffly. Finally, Medical Technician #2 looks back up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, we've processed your results. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You demonstrate something we call a competition phenomenon. FRED (getting up to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you. Medical Technician #2 gestures for Fred to sit.         H MEDICAL TECHNICIAN   #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a competition between your   left and right hemispheres. Kind of    like you have two gas gauges on your   car, one says your tank is full, the   other says it's empty. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I have two gas gauges? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Substance D. Damage has taken place in the normally dominant left hemisphere. The right hemisphere is attempting to compensate for the impairment. But the twin functions do not fuse. Now, we could perform a right hemispherectomy -- FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will these go away?    These gas gauges? MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably a functional impairment. MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be organic. Maybe permanent. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I'm confused.    Are you saying it is organic, or -- MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if it's brain damage, there are experiments now in the removal of small sections of both hemispheres which seem to abort compete gestalt- processing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MEDICAL TECHNICIAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the problem then is the individual only receives partial incoming sense data. Instead of having two signals, he gets half a signal. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a gas gauge?      What would that be like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank and a sweating Jim Barris sit at a table, the centerpiece of which is a reel-to-reel tape recorder. uniformed cop stands at the door. TAPE RECORDER VOICE (FEMALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I can't talk. I'll call you back. TAPE RECORDER VOICE (MALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't wait. The door to Hank's office opens. Hank switches off the ta recorder. A scramble suit enters, out of breath in a computerized-sounding way. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Sorry I'm late.   I just... Hank waves him off, turns on the tape recorder.       Fre TAPE RECORDER VOICE (FEMALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what is it then? TAPE RECORDER VOICE (MALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intend to... Hank switches off the tape, looks at Barris. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you identify the voices for us? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female's voice is a Miss Donna Hawthorne. The male is Bob Arctor. Hank nods, switches back on the tape.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TAPE RECORDER VOICE (MALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... half of Southern California tomorrow night. The Air Force Arsenal at Vandenberg AFB will be hit for automatic and semi-automatic weapons. TAPE RECORDER VOICE (FEMALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that disorientation drug the bikers ripped off for us? When do we carry that crud up to the watershed area to -- TAPE RECORDER VOICE (MALE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The organization needs the weapons first. The drugged water supply is step B. Hank turns off the tape. JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can identify the biker gang also. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have more material of this sort? JIM BARRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much more. Much much more.     Much much much much much -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, great. What I'm going to do, Mr. Barris, is impound this material here for further study. You will be held in custody, charged with giving false information. This is, of course, only a pretext for your own safety, but the formal charge will be lodged anyhow. Is that satisfactory? Hank does not wait for a response, but signals for the uniformed cop to lead Barris from the room. Barris continues to grin as he is led away. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your response, Fred, to Barris's evidence so far? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that my medical report, Hank? Hank nods, but offers nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think the little Barris played sounded genuined to me. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a fake, Fred, for Christ sake. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be right. But I don't agree. Um, so what does my medical report -- HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says you're completely cuckoo. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely? FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wie kalt ist es in diesem unterirdischen Gewolbe! HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe two brain cells still light up. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of how many, would you say? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I understand brains have a lot of cells. Fred looks down. HANK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I'd do, Fred. I wouldn't go into a federal clinic. I'd get about six bottles of good bourbun, go up into the hills, and just stay there till it's over. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me it may never be over. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then never come back.   Can you drive? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My... Fred's sense of the room begins to shift. The walls move toward infinity. Everything slows down. He watches Hank drum his fingers on the table. It takes forever for the

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: fingers to drop. When they hit, it is with a resounding "plop." Hank speaks, and it breaks the spell. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get somebody to drive you. FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ein Engel, der Gattin, so gleich, der fuhrt, mich zur Freheit ins... FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Thanks. (beat) Tell me, Hank, what do you think of me now, now that I've burned out? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're a very good person. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a cigarette? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm quitting them, too.   I'm quitting everything. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you. It's like I tell my children -- FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have kids, too.   Two little girls. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you do.   You're not supposed to.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF ARCTOR FAMILY PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Now all the faces, including Arctor's, are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're going to make it in the mountains, even if we get someone to drive you. Where else would you like to go?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about over to Donna Hawthorne's? I know you're close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By a process of elimination we were able to determine you're Bob Arctor. FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified, confused) Arctor?    I'm Bob Arctor?  But he's ugly! HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevermind. It's not important. (into phone) Get me a Donna Hawthorne at... (to Fred) Where does she work? FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Thompson Jewelers.   I'm Arctor? HANK (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... at Thompson Jewelers. (to Fred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should probably get you to a hospital. Barris poisoned you. It was really Barris, we were interested in. That's why we set up the scanners. He's into something heavy and sick, and it has to do with guns. FRED (massaging temples)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, wait, you used me to get to Barris? HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had to get to him, Bob. He's bad news. We couldn't tell you. We were afraid you'd spill the beans.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, weakly) You fuckers. You fuckers. The intercom buzzes. Hank flips off his voice grid, picks the phone. It's the first time we hear his real voice. HANK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Donna? This is a buddy of Bob's. He's in a bad way. I'm not jiving you. So could you pick him up, ... Fred watches Hank, sounding like a head, looking like a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna drives a sick Bob Arctor along a tree-lined road. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we go to New-Path, Bob, I thought maybe we'd drive into the hills, y'know, look at the city lights. Donna waits for a response, there is none. She glances ov at Arctor. He rests his forehead against the window. She sighs. Suddenly he begins to heave and vomit. Donna pulls onto the shoulder, gets out of the car, hurries to the passenger side to help Arctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is on his hands and knees vomiting. Donna kneels beside him, holding his forehead. He finishes. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's sit a few minutes. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (so weakly) Do you have any hash? Donna looks at him for a second, gets up, fusses around under the passenger seat, and pulls out a piece of foil a a pipe. She takes Arctor by the hand. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's get off the road a little bit. In case of cops. Donna and Arctor walk through the trees in silence, arriv at a clearing, from which the city lights can be seen. Sh sits Arctor down, fills the pipe, lights it, and draws. S passes the pipe to Arctor, but he is shivering and glassy eyed. A big, dark stain is forming on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. She inhales, leans forward to super-charge Arctor. But he doubles over, clutching his stomach. He vomits and moans crazy song-like moan, attempting to comfort himself. Donn touches his hand. But he is unaware of it. She sits on a rock and stares at the city lights below. DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we never know what's in store for us. Arctor continues to clutch himself and moan. DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know this dude Tony Amsterdam? No response from Arctor.    Donna relights the pipe, inha DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After he saw God, he felt really good, for around a year. Then he felt worse than he had ever felt before in his life. Because one day it came to him, he was never going to see God again. He was going to live out the rest of his life, fifty years maybe, and see nothing but what he had always seen. He realized he was going to have to live on and on with no purpose. Just a lump of flesh grinding along, eating, drinking, working, sleeping, crapping -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just... like... the... rest... of us. DONNA   HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I told   him. We're all in the same boat, and   it doesn't freak us out. But he said,    "You don't know what I saw." A spasm passes through Arctor, convulsing him.       Then BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did... he say what it was like? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spars. Showers of colored sparks. In the air. Going up the wall. Wherever he looked. The whole world (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: was a living creature. And there were no accidents. Everything fitted together to achieve something, some goal in the future. And there was a doorway. For a week he saw it wherever he looked. Always the same proportions, very narrow. Very pleasing. That's the word he used. He never entered it though. Just looked at it, surrounded by red and gold light, like the sparks had collected into lines. Then he never saw it again his whole, entire life. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was on the other side? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said it was always nighttime. Moonlight and water. Nothing ever changed. Water like blank ink and a beach. He was sure it was ancient Greece, that the door was a weak link in time. Later when he couldn't see it anymore, he became so frustrated with the noise and lights and motion in this world. He'd tell everyone he met that he lost everything. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost everything. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a woman on the island. More like a statue. Of the Cyrenaican Aphrodite. In the moonlight. Pale and cold. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should've gone through while he had the chance. You only get one chance. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't have the chance, Bob. It was a promise. Something to come. Something better a long time in the future. They show us trailers now. (puts arm around Arctor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we'll hold out.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you're trying to do. With me now. Show me a trailer. So I'll hold out. Donna is quiet, sniffs in some snot. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man. You've been dealt a bad blow. But life isn't over for you. I care for you a lot. I wish... Donna's voice cracks. She looks down at Arctor, who seems only semi-conscious now. She continues to hold him in silence, rocking him slightly, looking out at the city. DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good and kind person. And this is unfair, but it has to be this way. Try to wait for the end. Sometime, a long time from now, you'll see the way you saw before. A light shines into Donna's eyes. She squints at it, at t silhouette of a uniformed cop behind the light. COP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you stand, you first, miss, and show me your identification, please? Donna lays Arctor gently on the ground. She approaches th cop, signals him away from the unconscious Arctor, and ha him her wallet. He studies it in his flashlight beam. COP (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fed? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down. COP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fucking take off. The cop shines his flashlight into Donna's face, studies her, hands her her wallet, then takes off. Donna approach the unconscious Arctor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob?   We've got to get started. No answer.    She tugs at him, trying to rouse him. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make love. My thing's disappeared. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, they're expecting us.   I have to sign you in. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what'll I do if my thing's disappeared? Will they still take me? DONNA HAWTHORNE (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll take you. Donna helps Arctor up and walks him back to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor lies on the floor, curled up and shivering. Dried vomit flecks his face. The stain on his pants is bigger now. Two New-Path staff members stand surveying the trembling Arctor. Donna kneels at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Substance D? Donna nods. NEW-PATH #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ate his head. Another loser. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to win. Anybody can win. Donna bends down close to Arctor's face and silently mout "good-bye." She rises and heads to the door. A staff member drapes Arctor with a blanket as Donna exits. She does not look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna drives her tiny MG on the freeway in heavy traffic behind a huge Coca Cola truck. She picks a tape from the show box in the back. It's Carole King's Tapestry. She plugs it in and cranks it up loud, then pulls a pistol ou from under the dashboard. She unrolls the window, sticks the pistol out, and begins firing at the Coke truck. She hits it several times before the clip is emptied. Broken Coke bottle glasses and brown liquid splatter her windshi This soothes her for a moment, but misery builds up in he again almost instantly. To relieve it, she floors it and smashes into the truck with all her might. The impact spi the MG around. Tires shriek against fender as her car com to rest on the shoulder facing against traffic. Water pou from her radiator. Her headlights dim. Donna gets out of the car and looks at the Coke truck. It is still grinding along, seemingly untouched. Motorists gape at Donna as th crawl by. One guy unrolls his window. MOTORIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride, miss? She ignores him and heads back on foot to the exit ramp, squinting into the headlights of the oncoming traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, a staff member, addresses the camera as he leads down a dormitory hallway. GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Bruce, what you'll be doing here first is the bathrooms. George stops at a closet door, opens it, and pulls out a mop, pail, and some powdered soap. He closes the door, an continues down the hall. GEORGE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floors, the basins, and especially the toilets. There are three bathrooms, one on each floor. Okay, Bruce? Angle on Bruce. We see that Bruce is Bob Arctor. It is, however, a different Arctor: hair cut short and unstylish nondescript Goodwill clothing, and a mousy demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. George pushes open another door and enters.       Arctor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor and George stand in a dorm-style bathroom, with several toilets. George hands the mop and pail to Arctor. GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel you know how to clean a bathroom?   Start, and I'll give you some pointers. Arctor nods obediently, takes the pail to the sink, sprinkles in some soap flakes, and begins to fill it with water. He becomes transfixed with the foam forming in the pail and the roar of the running water. After a while, George speaks, sounding very far away. GEORGE (O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fill it all the way, Bruce, or you won't be able to lift it. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits with a paper cup of coffee. There are others the lounge, but they pay him no attention. He stares down at his coffee, focused on the rising and swirling steam. Jabbering is heard in the background. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could see from inside a dead person, you could still see, but you couldn't operate the eye muscles so you couldn't focus. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.   Just blurry. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, you couldn't turn your head or your eyeballs. All you could do is wait and wait until some object passed by. It'd be a terrible scene.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NEW-PATH RESIDENT #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's what it means to be dead. To not be able to stop looking at whatever's in front of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits on a folding chair in a semi-circle of reside and a staff member. He stares down at his hands. A portable blackboard is covered with scribbled words, such "Goals", "Responsibility", and "Community." A large coffe urn percolates in the corner, making a "whoop-whoop" soun Arctor focuses on this sound, which frightens him. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living and unliving things are exchanging properties. All murmer agreement except Arctor, who just looks down. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because the drive of the unliving is stronger than the drive of the living. Whoop-Whoop.    The coffee urn gets progressively louder. NEW-PATH STAFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we are incorporating too much unliving drive within us. Now, activity does not necessarily mean life. Quasars are active, but not alive. A meditating monk is not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with sad-looking people at collapsible tables eating dinner off trays. Arctor sits at a table by himself, and stares down at his steaming soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of residents excitedly rifle through a cardboard of donated clothing. Arctor stands back from the box and look at his feet. Mike, a short, stocky man with a pug fa slips into a shirt that looks like an American flag. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike, you're one sharp dude!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. Mike fiddles with a belt with two metal rings for a buckl He can't cinch it. MIKE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Oh, c'mon, you guys left me the belt nobody else could work! (to Arctor) You know how to do this, man? Arctor reaches down and cinches the belt. MIKE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks, buddy! Mike touches Arctor's shoulder.    Arctor glances at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits in the center of the room. A circle of residents yell at him. A Chinese girl is more shrill than the others CHINESE GIRL RESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he is? A kissy-face! You're a kissy-face! NEW-PATH RESIDENTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Can you fuck yourself? Can you fuck yourself? The Executive Director smiles from the circle. NEW-PATH RESIDENT #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see you fuck yourself! CHINESE GIRL RESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kissy-facy! Another female resident flaps her arms and bulges her che in Arctor's face. The Chinese girls swivels around and sticks her ass in Arctor's face. CHINESE GIRL RESIDENT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass, kissy-facy! He wants to kiss people, kiss this, kissy-facy!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NEW-PATH RESIDENTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see you fuck yourself, kissy- facy! Arctor shuts his eyes, but still hears the screaming. The Executive Director clears his throat; the screaming subsi EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pimp. You fuck. You dong. You shit. You turd. You snot. You asshole. You vomit. You wart. We shift to Arctor's POV, looking out at the group and hearing the Executive Director's chant. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bile. You worm. You maggot. You pus. You running sore. The chanting continues, but the actual words become indecipherable. Mike's voice breaks the chant. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Bruce? Arctor looks at Mike's compassionate face. MIKE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, what's the matter? What brought you here? Can you tells us anything about yourself? Your past? NEW-PATH RESIDENT #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pimp!   What are you, pimp? CHINESE GIRL RESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, you cock-sucking fairy whore pimp! You ass-kisser, you fuck! BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am an eye. I am dead. I can only look at what is front of me. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turd prick. You weakling. You puke. You suck-off. You snatch. The Executive Director continues, but Arctor can't make o the words as he surveys the cold, hard faces of the group Spade Weeks is among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor walks down the hall, carrying his pail and mop. He passes an open door. Inside is a brightly lit room in whi several children play. Arctor watches, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children sit at a table in an alcove off the main din area. Some of the smaller children sit in high chairs and are being fed by old men. Arctor watches from outside the alcove. Mike walks by. He smiles. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like kids, Bruce? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can eat with them if you like. Arctor nods and sits at the end of the table. MIKE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can feed them in a month or two. After we're sure you won't hit them. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is mostly empty now. Only a couple of stragglin children and Arctor remain. The two old men are beginning clean-up. One of the children goes, leaving only Arctor a a wide-eyed little girl. LITTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name? Arctor doesn't respond. LITTLE GIRL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, what's your name? My name is Thelma. Did you forget your name? If you forget your name, you can write it on your hand. Want me to show you how? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't it wash off?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LITTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. (thinking) Well, you could write on the ceiling above your bed. Then when you want to know your name better, you can -- BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma. LITTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's my name. And that's a girl's name anyway. If I see you again, I'll give you a name. I'll make one up for you. 'kay? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you live here? LITTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but my mommy may be leaving. She's thinking about taking us, me and my brother, and leaving. 'kay, Bye! She runs off.    Arctor watches after the girl. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor sits on a folding chair against the wall, staring his cup of coffee. Mike walks by in his bright new shirt. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bruce! Arctor looks up. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you leaving here? MIKE (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, I can never leave   here. Too many temptations out there   for the likes of us. No, I'm just    going into town to pick up a donation   of semi- rotten vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semi-rotten vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NOTEBOOK DAPPLED WITH SUNLIGHT
dialogues.text: kids laughing in background.    We scan the following wor read offhandedly by Arctor. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part... The camera pulls back to reveal that it's Donna reading t journal. She's sitting at a picnic table outside a McDonald's. Her eyes move back and forth across the page. Near her, a group of children laugh and play on a McDonaldland jungle gym. BOB ARCTOR (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but then shall I know even as also I am known. That's the last entry. She closes the notebook, takes a s of Coke, and watches the children play. A pick-up truck pulls into the parking lot. Mike gets out, approaches Donna's table, sits across from her. There's a silence, then: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are they paranoid about him? MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He just sits there all day. There's really nothing to suspect. They can't get anything out of him during the game sessions. Donna looks off for a moment, sadly. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, will he be able to act, when the time comes? Is anything left? MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never really know. A memory. A few charred brain cells flicker on. People like him are clacking insects. All reflex. We can only hope he's got the right reflex.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was very well drilled into him. (forlorn) Such a price to pay. The government asks an awful lot. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life asks an awful lot. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) In this case, the fucking government. Bob didn't volunteer. He was sacrificed. He was my friend, y'know. (beat) I don't want to be on this assignment much longer. I just want it over. Shit. Sometimes I think we're colder than they are. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a warm person when I look at you, Donna. DONNA HAWTHORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm warm on the outside. Warm face, warm eyes, warm fucking fake smile. But inside I'm cold all the time. I am full of lies. I am awful. Donna gets up and walks away.    Mike watches after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor opens the door to the room where he first saw the children. In there now is an old woman trying to juggle. smiles at Arctor and he sees that she has almost no teeth OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do this? She throws the balls in the air to juggle and they fall b onto her then bounce onto the floor. She stoops over, spitting and laughing. Arctor is dismayed. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can. She tries again, fails, laughs. A staffer appears next to the Arctor in the doorway, sniffs the air

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NEW-PATH STAFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, you need to clean yourself. You stink. BOB ARCTOR (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna?! The old woman shuffles past Arctor and the staffer. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has Donna been here? NEW-PATH STAFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Six months. BOB ARCTOR (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, then it's not Donna. I've been here a week. And Donna drove me here. And she was fine: sad-eyed, quiet and composed. So beautiful. Leather jacket. That purse with the rabbit's foot dangling. Just like always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor and Mike sit across from each other over coffee. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to try to get you a job on one of our farms, Bruce. When you're ready. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I work with animals. I like animals. Can I work with them? MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to try you with crops.    I think that'd be good for you. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to work with something living. MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground is living. Do you have any agricultural background? BOB ARCTOR (searching memory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to work in an office.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'll be outside from now on, sowing, tilling, killing insects. We do a lot of that with pesticides. But we're very careful, because those sprays can poison the crop as well as the person using them. Eat his head. The way yours has been eaten, Bruce. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor is pulling some cleaning supplies from the cabinet under the sink. He notices something, picks it up, studie it. It's a bone fragment. He gets frightened, turns to someone cutting vegetables, and holds up the bone. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Jerry Fabin?! Is this Jerry Fabin?! The person takes the bone fragment, looks at it, and shru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hot, bright day. A car drives in through the gate the razor-wire fenced farm, and raises dust as it heads toward a cluster of wooden houses. It stops and Arctor steps out, pulling a suitcase after him. He is met at the car by the farm manager, a middle-aged man with a sun- creased face. The car drives off. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Bruce. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Bruce. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Westaway recommended we give you a try on the farm. You're going to work here for a while. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll like it better here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll like it better here. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like mountains? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like mountains. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful mountains all around. The manager points, but Arctor does not look. FARM MANAGER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the air is good. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like air. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bruce, we all like air. We really all do. C'mon, I'll show you your bunk and get you a hat to protect your head from the sun. The manager leads Bruce to the bunkhouses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's crude with six cots.    The manager points to one of FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where you sleep. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I be seeing my friends? FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean back at the rehab? BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Thelma and Donna and Jerry Fabin and Luckman and Barris and -- FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farms are closed facilities, so they can't come visit. Besides you're not supposed to make any one-to-one relationships at New-Path. Didn't they teach you that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had us memorize that as part of the New-Path creed. The farm manager studies Arctor's sad, blank face. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we usually send you back to your residence-of-origin for holidays. So you'll be visiting at Thanksgiving if you do good work. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanksgiving. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then. What else? (looks around, points) Bathroom there. And you can turn on and off the light with this cord. Arctor is no longer paying attention. He's caught a glimp of the mountains out the window, and stands transfixed. FARM MANAGER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountains, Bruce, mountains. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountains, Bruce, mountains. FARM MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echolalalia, Bruce, echolalalia. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echolalalia, Bruce, echolalalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctor, in a cap and carrying a pesticide sprayer, wades through the stalks, checking for insect infestation. His entire focus, his entire consciousness is directed at thi task. His hat blows off, and he bends to pick it up. As h nears the ground, he notices a second crop growing underneath, hidden by the corn. It's a small, bright blue flower, and now that he's close to the ground, he can see planted everywhere. He squats there, transfixed. Someone comes up behind him. It's the Executive Director of New- Path. Arctor doesn't look up; he just stares at the flowe EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're seeing the flower of the future, Bruce. But not for you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not for me? EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've had too much of a good thing. So get up and stop worshipping. This isn't your god anymore. Arctor keeps staring. The Executive Director reaches down and holds his open hand in Arctor's field of vision. Arct doesn't move his head; he just continues to stare, now at Executive Director's hand. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone.     The flowers of spring are gone. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You simply can't see them. That's a philosophical problem you wouldn't comprehend. Epistemology -- the theory of knowledge. Arctor stares forever at the palm of the Executive Director's rich, uncalloused hand, sees every crease. Finally: EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, back to work, Bruce. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw. The Executive Director chuckles, rises, and heads off. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to work, Bruce. Now that the hand is gone, Arctor stares once again at th blue flowers. The colors shift, grow more saturated. FAR-AWAY VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Substance D. I saw death rising from the earth itself, in one blue field. In very slow motion, Arctor picks a blue flower, and puts inside his shoe. Shift back to normal speed and color. BOB ARCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A present for my friends. (fond smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends who I'll see soon.   At Thanksgiving.
